column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112376,2023,Seminar Regional and Transport Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['G Mingardo', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Cities and regions are going through a constant process of economic, social and spatial change. This applies to the most successful global cities but also to those cities that had to go through (or are still going through) a process of economic restructuring because their dominant industries collapsed. This continuous economic, social, and spatial development of cities can strengthen its competitive position but for cities struggling to reinvent their economies, it can be (and possibly still is) a painful process. Additionally, urban areas, companies and citizens increasingly face problems in terms of accessibility and mobility. Congestion, pollution and social exclusion are only some of the major challenges that decision makers have to address. And they have to do this in a fast-changing world; in recent years new forms of mobility (sharing-, electric-, micro-, floating-mobility) have developed at a fast pace. Finally, the recent COVID-19 crisis will most probably influence the way we travel for a while. Hence, the economic and transport development of cities and regions are topics that are high on the agenda of companies, policymakers, practitioners and academics.

In this seminar, the objective is to develop the ability to give strategic advice to stakeholders in order to increase their competitiveness. Students learn to use different research methods (i.e. data analysis, case study, surveys etc.) in order to come up with intelligent solutions to the most common urban and transport problems. These skills can be used by students when conducting research for their master thesis.
Some seminar sessions might include guest speakers’ presentations. In the last years this seminar has covered the following topics:

These topics are discussed based on the latest scientific insights and real-life case study. Students are stimulated to use a variety of research tools to analyse actual challenges. This is an intensive course that combines interactive group discussions, the writing of weekly individual essays, (field) assignments as well as empirical group work and assignments.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To deepen the knowledge on specific regional and transport problems by advanced scientific readings.
• To develop the ability to apply research and methodological tools to analyse contemporary regional and transport challenges.
• To develop accurate and sound economic strategic advice for stakeholders.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This seminar is devoted to the analysis and management of risks and complements Financial Risk Management (FEM11023). Throughout the course, we will study in detail how risk management applies to both banks and non-financial companies. You will learn about liquidity management as well as hedging using derivates. We will delve into the relation between risk management and financial regulation. Finally, we will discuss novel types of risks associated with the advancement of financial innovations and the challenges of climate change. Through group assignments, various theoretical and practical topics in derivatives, hedging, and risk analysis are explored in depth.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the theory and practice of financial risk management.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into recent developments in financial innovation and financial regulation.
• Students are able to apply standard measures to evaluate market and credit risks.
• Students are able to apply risk management tools to hedge a portfolio.
• Students are able to write a research assignment.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To achieve its learning goals, this seminar combines a hands-on marketing strategy simulation (StratSim) with discussion-based sessions (lectures, coaching, and cases), which allows us to offer you important insights that can become the cornerstone of a career in marketing, consulting, corporate strategy, or entrepreneurship.
In particular, we will embrace four common tension points in marketing strategy:
1. The tension between the short and the long term
2. The tension between targeted and focused marketing efforts (i.e., a local approach) and mass market appeal (i.e., a global approach)
3. The tension between volume and profit margin
4. The tension between insights and evidence, and the need for assumptions and intuition when making decisions under uncertainty
Thus, we will make strategic marketing decisions for simulated firms and for a total of 7-8 simulated years, which will allow us to feel and practice how to handle these tensions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Learning and practicing marketing strategy (i.e., we will bridge the “theory” and the “practice” of strategic marketing.
• Learning and practicing evidence-based decision-making (i.e., we will learn the benefits and limitations of market research data and insights for strategic marketing decisions).

• Gaining soft skills and teamwork skills (we will work in a diverse large team, comparable in size to a strategic leadership team, and learn how to divide roles, adopt decision processes and join efforts to make better decisions).
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The content of the seminar is fourfold. Two group assignments:
1. Solving a business case on a strategy issue using relevant insights from the academic literature and available data to the best extent.

2. Collecting and summarizing research papers to give an overview of relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy. Providing a critical assessment of the literature to identify a relevant research question for further research.
3. Presenting a research paper in class to give an insight in relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy. Answering questions from fellow students and moderating a class discussion.
4. Writing a summary on each of the research questions discussed in class with critical assessment of the presented papers.
1. Can successful management practices be transferred across countries and firms?
2. What is the impact of top managers on the performance of firms?
3. Can firms acquire new technology by hiring workers?
4. What is the effect of entry regulation on economic performance?
5. Why are firms using other firms to produce their output?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Read and understand state-of-the-art economic literature on strategy, managerial economics and firm entry and exit.
• Summarize and communicate insights from scientific papers on industrial dynamics and strategy in a class presentation.
• Search and analyse firm data in a group project to solve a business case related to entry strategy.
• Write an informed opinion on current topics in industrial dynamics and strategy research based on relevant literature.
• Conduct an in-depth literature review and define a relevant research question on a specialized topic in industrial dynamics and strategy.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This seminar gives a quantitative insight into the design of a supply chain. It provides a tool-box in terms of research skills (Optimization through Excel ,statistics skills and finding data), theory and methods in order to be able to analyze and optimize supply chains, focusing on costs, time as well as CO2 emissions. We focus on a realistic case for transporting white goods from China to Europe. The case serves to get hands-on experience in the considerations for choosing between different transport modes (ship, truck or rail), cost structures, selection of distribution network type, port choices and locations of distribution centers. Finally we also evaluate environmental issues relating to supply chains. The required theory will be given in lectures at the start of the seminar.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To understand the effect of various supply chain drivers.
• To be able to analyse a supply chain according to various characteristics (costs, time and CO2 emissions).
• To be able to apply supply chain design and transport chain models.
• To develop the research skills and methods necessary to analyze and optimize supply chains w.r.t costs and environmental criteria.
• To develop computer skills for supply chain calculations and visualising.
• To be able to obtain and assess the quality of data and overcome data requirements for logistic networks
• To present results in a clear and convincing way.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This seminar covers recent topics in International Economics. Among others, the following questions are explored: Does international economic integration promote economic growth? What are the determinants of the exchange rate and the trade balance? What are the causes and effects of balance of payment crises? When do fixed exchange rate regimes and monetary unions work? How does international economic integration affect international relations? The seminar combines economic theory, quantitative empirical evidence, and historical case studies to throw light on these questions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1) Familiarize yourself with the most important International Economics theories on:

column2: • the interplay of global markets for goods, capital, and labor
• the interaction of monetary policy, exchange rates, and trade balances
• trade surpluses/deficits and balance of payment crises
• fixed exchange rate regimes and monetary unions (e.g. euro area)

column1: 2) Get to know the quantitative empirical evidence that compares the practical relevance of different International Economics theories
3) Obtain a big-picture overview of the history of the world economy and learn how International Economics can help you to understand it better

column1: In the seminar of major Urban, Port and Transport Economics, students analyze a spatial economic question. The seminar develops an economic location choice framework. Supplemented with spatial analysis (GIS) and empirical analysis of commuting (gravity equations), students simulate the spatial effects of a real-life economic scenario, such as the construction of new houses, new rail or road infrastructure, or structural economic change. An introduction to working with and visualizing spatial data is part of the course. In addition, students analyze a parallel problem from the logistical side, applying more qualitative methods.

• To formulate advise based on economic research.
• To present and defend research and recommendations in written and verbal form.
• To organise work and cooperate in a group.

column1: The Seminar in Business Analytics aims to apply and possibly extend econometric and machine/deep learning techniques in a business context. At the central stage is the customer in a broad sense of its meaning aiming to benefit from a business analysis. Examples of questions related to this topic are: How to recommend products to customers?, How to summarize sentiment information from product reviews?, How to make predictions that can help customers make better decisions? How to aggregate heterogeneous product information? The domain of applications is broad, some examples are: e-commerce, marketing, finance, politics, and sports. The data can come in different modalities: numeric, text, image, sound, or video, which means techniques from statistics, knowledge representation, natural language processing, and computer vision can also be used.

Examples of research topics are: market/business forecasting, credit default prediction, anomaly detection, sentiment mining, recommender systems, and duplicates detection. Groups of four students will work on a business analytics topic, spanning a full research trajectory composed of: research question formulation, related work analysis, methodology design and implementation, results evaluation and interpretation, and research summarization and future work suggestion. Students will need to present various research artifacts, show critical thinking, and write a short scientific paper based on the results of their work. The datasets will be provided as well as guidance in selecting an appropriate research question.
This course uses knowledge from FEB22009(X,Q) Introductory Seminar Case Studies and FEB23002 Marketing Models.

column1: Economic forecasting plays a key role in macroeconomics, monetary policy decisions, labor market decisions and quantitative finance. It is an indispensable tool at central banks, different governmental institutions and various financial institutions. The seminar focuses on both theoretical foundations and practical implementation aspects on how to construct good forecasts, how to evaluate whether our constructed forecasts are good enough, and how to compare competing forecasts given by different methods. Within this general framework, the topic of the seminar revolves around the following research questions:

column2: • How to forecast and compare forecasts in unstable environments (for e.g., covid recession)?
• How can machine learning be useful for forecasting?
• How to forecasts inflation in the current high inflation times?

column1: This course uses knowledge from FEB22009(X,Q) Introductory Seminar Case Studies, FEB21022(X) Macroeconomics and FEB23016 Advanced Econometrics.

column1: In this seminar we discuss econometric and financial research related to investing. In particular, you learn how to form and evaluate optimal portfolios. Relevant research questions include “How should an investor optimally distribute wealth? What estimates are needed to implement these allocations? What estimators are suitable given features of the data? How can we evaluate and compare empirical performance? What are the practical shortcomings of the allocations?”. To explore this topic, we address fundamental features historically associated with equity markets. This includes the importance of diversification and timing for investing. From this starting point we consider the econometric methods required for a successful implementation of optimal portfolios. We carefully discuss potential limitations such as parameter uncertainty and its practical implications. Based on literature covered in the first three weeks of the case studies, you are able to delve into the most recent research and formulate your own proposal. The research projects are conducted by groups of four students.
This course uses knowledge from FEB22009(X,Q) Introductory Seminar Case Studies, FEB23006 Quantitative Methods in Finance and FEB23016 Advanced Econometrics.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Data is known to be the oil and gold of the 21st century. However, surprisingly few professionals have enough skills to ensure the best use of this resource. With the growing availability of data, machine learning is becoming increasingly important in strategic decision-making and problem solving. Data-driven solutions can deliver benefits in virtually every industry ranging from credit scoring models and image recognition to self-driving cars and content selection on Netflix. Various machine learning techniques can uncover highly complex relationships in data which can be used for the strategic decision-making process. With the help of insights gained from structured or unstructured data, organizations hope to gain a competitive advantage and efficiency.

In this seminar, students will be introduced to the broad field of machine learning with its main concepts and principles. The students will be introduced to such central methods of machine learning as penalized regression, tree-based methods, and neural networks. Subsequently, methods for text analytics and cluster analysis will be discussed. All methods will be illustrated by concrete practical examples. Finally, the students will apply the gained knowledge to work on their own projects. After finalizing this seminar, students will acquire the necessary skills to consider data science problems from different angles, including managerial and technical.
As a result of successful studies students:

column2: • will be able to solve real-world problems by identifying a suitable machine learning tool;
• will have the necessary skills to analyze the validity of machine learning algorithms for different types of data (binary, categorical, discrete, numerical, text, image, audio);
• will be able to select most suitable techniques by performing evaluation of learning algorithms and model selection;
• will create policy recommendations for companies by transforming results produced by machine learning algorithms.

column1: This course uses knowledge from FEB22009(X,Q) Introductory Seminar Case Studies, FEB22002(X) Introduction to Multivariate Statistics and FEB22005(X) Econometrics 2.

column1: In this seminar you learn how to apply methods in Econometrics and Operations Research to logistics. Logistics is a broad and important application area of Operation Research. Questions to be answered when solving a practical problem are: “What is a suitable optimization model, what data is required to optimize the model, and how can the results be interpreted and applied?” The seminar explores state-of-the-art mathematical modeling and optimization techniques focusing both on the theoretical background and the practical implementation. The practical implementation consists of a case study conducted by a group of three or four students.
Examples of case studies in recent years are:

column2: • Optimization of the production of concrete floors at Dycore
• Design of a maintenance policy for a fleet of specialized multipurpose survey vessels
• Planning audit visits to suppliers for Philips
• Planning and routing of recycling trucks on a Danish peninsula
• Service level optimization at the customer service center of a big insurance company

column1: Each year students will work on a case that is different from any case in previous years.
This course uses knowledge from FEB22009(X,Q) Introductory Seminar Case Studies, FEB23004 Quantitative Methods for Logistics and FEB23007 Data Structures and Algorithms.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111119,2023,Sensitivity and Competence in the Diverse Educational Context,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. DT van Dijk'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the practical ‘Sensitivity and Competence in the Diverse Educational Context’ is to support students and give students tools to become aware of, develop and strengthen their own sensitivity and competences with regards to diversity in society, and in the daily practices within education. Students will share their own experiences and stories with diversity-related topics, and encounter and investigate those of (marginalized) professionals in the educational field. In this way, the environment of the student is used as a starting point in the process of becoming aware of and developing diversity-related sensitivity and competences. Subsequently, students take their insights further into the educational field. In addition, students apply their gained knowledge and skills to real-life educational settings. Finally, students integrate and reflect on their gained experiences, insights, and understanding of their own (view on) sensitivity and competence in the diverse educational context.
Following completion of this course, students are able to do each of the following:
1. Be aware of (in)equity and in/exclusion in society and educational practice;
2. Describe and evaluate strengths and limitations of their own knowledge, expertise, norms, and values regarding diversity in the educational profession;
3. Formulate responsibilities and actions within their own professional development regarding (in)equity in society and educational practice;
4. Act sensitive and competent in diversity-related situations (i.e., they act in an inclusive way);
5. Investigate, by means of a podcast exercise, the experiences and responsibilities of professionals in urban education regarding (in)equity in society and educational practice.

column1: When mental illnesses become complex, chronic, and comorbid, they may hit the limits of traditional mental health care. Especially when severe mental illnesses, such as psychosis spectrum disorders, go hand in hand with confused behaviour, comorbid conditions, homelessness, or other social problems, they are often considered difficult-to-treat. In this course, we take a different perspective on recovery in severe mental illness, to gain a new understanding of illness experience and meaningful outcome. We explore multidisciplinary, person-centred, process-based, and assertive outreach approaches, that incorporate personal and societal factors beyond the traditional clinical focus.

In this course, you will actively evaluate the merits of traditional and innovative diagnostic and treatment models for complex cases of severe mental illness. You are challenged to take a critical position regarding DSM-driven diagnosis and treatment. You reflect on methodological standards and ethical dimensions in mental health research, and their impact on clinical practice. Finally, you reflect on your role as health care professional, and work on a constructive use of language to facilitate meaningful recovery in severe mental illness.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, the student knows how to
1. Evaluate different models of psychopathology, treatment, and recovery.
2. Identify complex mental disorders and disabilities related to psychosis and ‘confused behaviour’.
3. Take a critical stance towards the use of the DSM and other diagnostic approaches in clinical practice and scientific research.
4. Reflect on research methods and their impact on clinical practice.
5. Explain the value of multidisciplinary research and practice versus standardized approaches in working with severe mental illness.
6. Reflect on their own role as a psychologist within a multidisciplinary team, including awareness of the ethical dimension of clinical practice.
7. Choose language that is sensitive to personal meaning and supportive to the recovery process.

column1: The department of Epidemiology, in collaboration with the department of Internal Medicine, offers medical and health professionals a short introductory one-day workshop on Gender & Health at Erasmus University Medical Center. To realize gender equality in health care, sex and gender dimension needs to be integrated in all aspects of research and clinical practice. This course brings together experts from a multitude of disciplines including clinical, basic science, public health and policy and provides participants with resources that will assist them in developing and strengthening gender-equal clinical care and research programs.
The purpose of the course is to provide participants interested in improving gender-equal health and well-being with essential knowledge and principal skills from several disciplines.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course. You will receive all details about the location and the final programme for the course one week prior to the start of the course.
1.To provide insight on the Erasmus MC policy of diversity
2. To provide insight on the importance of sex and gender in health care research
3. To provide tools how to implement in basic, epidemiological and clinical research
4. To provide knowledge on sex and gender in research funding

column4: Jeanine Roeters van Lennep, Internal Medicine, Erasmus MC
3. Sex & gender: considerations in health research I
4. Sex & gender: considerations in health research II
5. Sex, gender, and health: funding perspectives
6. Better science with sex and gender
Antoinette Maassen van den Brink, Internal Medicine, Erasmus MC
AFTERNOON  - Sex, gender & health: applications in research, education, and clinical care

column1: Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years.  On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the Master’s program, students have the opportunity to explore a professional field of interest by means of a Research Internship. Arrangements have been made with around 15-20 national and international archives, museums, research institutes, educational organizations and business companies for research projects which students may select as the subject for their Master’s thesis. Please note that this is not a policy-related internship; it involves an academic research project. The final product may be a publication, an international workshop, website, object analysis or exhibition storyline. This research activity covers 18 working days (5 ECTS). Some internships are linked to the research of a master thesis.

All internships will be announced at the end of term-1 on BlackBoard; there is also an indication whether an internship is linked to a master thesis subject. The internships will also be presented at the Master Thesis Market.

Each student formulates a working plan after consultation with the faculty supervisor and the supervisor of the internship institution. Based on that working plan, an official Agreement Research Internship Master History of Society will be signed by: the student, the supervisor of the institution and the faculty supervisor. The research internship will be completed with a report, written by the student according to the guidelines of the master. The report contains also appendixes with important outcomes and products (written or images of the products). The whole report and internship will be assessed during a final interview with the supervisors. Based on this interview the supervisor of the institution will write a general assessment. The faculty supervisor will assess whether the student
has reached the aims of this internship; there is no grade. For an explanation see the documents on the websitehttp://www.eshcc.eur.nl/english/history/mahs/current/researchinternship/.

column1: Prof. Dr. B.F. Heidergott (VU), Dr. A.A.N Ridder (VU)

Simulation Analysis & Optimization course addresses the use of computer simulation for the analysis and optimization of stochastic dynamic models. Applications will stem from a wide range of domains from Financial Engineering and Business Processes.

The course gives a broad treatment of the important aspects of Monte Carlo simulation and its applications in areas such as inventory control, project planning, reliability, risk analysis and financial models. The emphasis is on modeling the stochastic dynamic system as a discrete event system, and analyzing and improving its performance by means of discrete event simulation.

The topics covered include generating random numbers, selecting input distributions and model validation. The course also teaches the statistical output analysis and the use of simulation in optimization and learning.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students will be able to:
Knowledge and understanding: Understand sampling random objects, discrete event simulation, simulation based sensitivity analysis, statistical output analysis.

Application of knowledge: Model real-life problems by discrete-event models; conduct Monte Carlo simulation-based analysis of a problem and provide an output analysis; apply simulation in optimization and learning.
Making judgement: Draw conclusions from simulation output.
Communication: Report on their findings from a simulation study.

column1: Instructor: Dr. B.S.Y. Crutzen (EUR), Prof. Dr. P.P. Wakker (EUR).

The skill workshop series enables students to fine-tune skills needed for a successful academic career. The series opens by tackling important issues related to the scientific integrity, transparent algorithm and ethical data management, which are highly relevant for a business data scientist. In the second year, practical aspects related to how to handle the review process, and grant applications will be discussed. In these workshops, writing and positioning skills are emphasized. The series closes with a workshop on presentation skills for research talks and conference presentations.

column1: The small business is the most common type of business in every modern economy, and it is not just a scaled-down version of a large business. The course Small Business Economics is about the importance of small businesses and entrepreneurship for markets and economies. Main topics include the differences between small and large businesses, small business entry and exit, small business policy, small business growth and location strategy, social entrepreneurship and sustainability.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Being introduced to the world of small business economics and the economics of entrepreneurship
• Becoming familiar with the differences between small and large firms
• Gaining insight into entry and exit dynamics of small businesses as well as growth, innovation and sustainability strategies
• Understanding why governments support small businesses through policy and what policy instruments exist
• Using publicly available data about small businesses and entrepreneurship for making country comparisons.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course Small Business Economics has been completely revised, partly based on prior evaluations indicating that the course should cover topics a bit more in-depth and at a higher / more advanced level. Topics like entry and exit of small firms and small firm innovation are now covered in more detail and with a stronger focus on relevant theories that can be applied to these topics. Also new and timely topics like sustainability in small firms and the role of small firms in developing countries are now covered in this course. To make the course content more lively and accessible, stronger emphasis is put on discussing and incorporating real-life examples of small firms and their entrepreneurs.
The course will consist of the following three modules:
1. Small firms in the economy (small firm entry, exit and performance)
2. Innovation and sustainability in small firms

The assessment will be based on two group assignments (these assignments together account for 25% of the course grade) and an exam (which accounts for 75% of the course grade). At least one of the group assignments will be in collaboration with a firm / entrepreneur for which students will be asked to develop an advice for this firm on how it could best deal with some of the challenges that it is currently facing.</body>

column1: This program is specially developed for students from Leiden University, Delft University of Technology and Erasmus University Rotterdam. The 15 EC and 30 EC minor programme is combined.

The minor consists of three modules of 5 EC each for the 15 EC variety. The 30 EC variety holds four modules of 5 EC and 10 EC research work for an (external) commissioner. The format and modules include classic and innovative teaching methods, i.e., lectures and seminars, field trips, case-based group assignments, video production, and the integration of academia and practice. Students should choose the course load when registering for the minor. This is a full-time minor program – and participating in lectures and activities is mandatory.

The aim of the minor is to introduce students from the LDE universities through case-based education to the different smart city concepts and the underlying complexity of modern cities, focused on urban technologies and data science with citizen experience and multi-stakeholder governance. The program is characterized by a multi-disciplinary approach, which allows students to take different perspectives and understand the complexity of smart city life. The learning goals concern knowledge, attitude, and skills which in combination need to equip students with a critical mindset that enables them to work towards public needs and interests in smart cities.

For this minor there is a balance between traditional and innovative learning methods. The modules are designed in a blended learning form, meaning lectures will make use of face-to-face lectures, online documents and articles, and video’s/online lectures. Reading materials include policy papers, reports, articles, and books. We will use Canvas as electronic teaching environments.
Reasons to choose a Leiden-Delft Erasmus minor:

column2: • You will receive multidisciplinary education from three top universities.
• You learn about urgent social issues and new solutions.
• You meet students and teachers from different fields of study.
• You work on cases for companies, governments, and NGOs.
• You build a network in Leiden, The Hague, Delft and Rotterdam.

column1: The purpose of this minor program is to educate professionals from different fields such social, economic, environmental engineering and political science on the importance of the different aspects in the use of Big, Open and Linked Data within creating the smart and shared city. This program intends to stimulate a reflective mindset, focusing on the interrelation of problems and responsible innovation.

The minor Smart and SHARED Cities is a full-time program that starts in September and ends in January. Each week consist of approximately 10 contact hours and 20 hours of self-study. There are designated days on which there are lectures and days on which you study the material and work together with peers on the projects. Students who are interested in the development of smart and shared cities and the digital society can follow this minor. The program is offered in English and is accessible for both national and international students.

column1: For students completing this minor, there are generic competences and specific competences to be acquired. The minor programme mainly focuses on skills such as analysing and evaluating (policies/strategies). After completing block A (15 EC programme), students will have acquired specific knowledge on smart cities and how data usage could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants.

For students completing this minor, there are generic competences and specific competences to be acquired. The minor programme mainly focuses on skills such as analysing and evaluating (policies/strategies). After completing block A (15 EC programme), students will have acquired specific knowledge on smart cities and how data usage could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants.
At the end of module 1, students will be able to:
• Explain the origins and function of the smart city concept.
• Identify key enabling technologies and methodologies of the smart city.
• Identify (recognize) and compare the different conceptions of the smart city concept.
• Position themselves in the smart city debate, argue for that position and reflect on that
At the end of module 2, students will be able to:
• Understand the relevance of citizen participation in smart cities.
• Compare different examples of citizen participation and their underlying paradigms in
• Reflect on different design approaches to accommodate transparency and actionability
for citizen participation in smart cities.
• Create a design proposal for transparency and civic actionability in smart cities.
At the end of module 3, students will be able to:
• Analyse complex governance processes in smart cities.
• Have a grasp of current discussions in the literature on governance-related aspects of
• Explain  the  role  of  different  stakeholders  in  the  smart  city  context,  especially  local
• Reflect on and compare different interests and point of views when using technology
and data in a smart city context.
• Evaluate smart city policies in light of vulnerable groups.</body>

column1: This minor is a fulltime program. Students are expected to participate in collective class activities  on  Monday,  Wednesday,  and  Friday  during  office  hours  (i.e.,  between  9:00  and  17:00). Tuesday and Thursday are for individual assignments and group work. The schedule will be  published on Canvas. You will be notified by changes via announcements.
The minor takes place at Erasmus University, TU Delft and Leiden University.
The assessment of module 1 consists of three individual assignments. The students will make
one  assignment  each  week.  The  first  assignment  is  a  paper  on  smart  city  concepts.  The
second assignment is a memo in which students give advice as a smart city expert. The third
assignment combines knowledge of the entire module for an analysis of a smart city.
Assignment 1 Actors and stakeholders in the city Individual 33,3%
Assignment 2 Advising the community on a smart city experiment Individual 33,3%
Assignment 3 Ethical and political analysis of a smart city Individual 33,3%
The assessment of module 2 consists of two assignments. The group assignment consists of
a  portfolio.  Each  week,  the  students  will  work  on  assignment  about  citizen  participation
rhetoric, citizen participation practice and design for citizen participation respectively. Together
these assignments form the portfolio. The individual assignment is a reflection on the outcome
The  assessment  of module  3 consists  of  one  individual  assignment:  a  policy  brief.  A  policy
brief presents a concise summary of information that can help the policymaker understand,
and likely make decisions about, government policies.
Assignment 1 Policy brief for an urban policymaker Individual 100,0%

The minor programme mainly focuses on skills such as analysing and evaluating (policies/strategies). After completing block A (15 EC programme), students will have acquired specific knowledge on smart cities and how data usage could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants.
At the end of module 1, students will be able to:
• Explain the origins and function of the smart city concept.
• Identify key enabling technologies and methodologies of the smart city.
• Identify (recognize) and compare the different conceptions of the smart city concept.
• Position themselves in the smart city debate, argue for that position and reflect on that
At the end of module 2, students will be able to:
• Understand the relevance of citizen participation in smart cities.
• Compare different examples of citizen participation and their underlying paradigms in
• Reflect on different design approaches to accommodate transparency and actionability
for citizen participation in smart cities.
• Create a design proposal for transparency and civic actionability in smart cities.
At the end of module 3, students will be able to:
• Analyse complex governance processes in smart cities.
• Have a grasp of current discussions in the literature on governance-related aspects of
• Explain  the  role  of  different  stakeholders  in  the  smart  city  context,  especially  local
• Reflect on and compare different interests and point of views when using technology
and data in a smart city context.
• Evaluate smart city policies in light of vulnerable groups.

After completing block B (30 EC programme), students will have acquired knowledge about urban data science, its advantages and limitations and how it could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants. The knowledge that students will acquire in these modules will be applied in a case project, where theory is applied in practice by means of a research project.
At the end of module 4, you will be able to:
• Identify new sources of spatiotemporal urban data, and ways to collect them.
• Compare different types of urban data based on their characteristics.
• Select appropriate sources of urban data to address problems of (smart) cities, relating
to a range of application domains (e.g., mobility, health, housing etc.);
• Explain  and  discuss  applications  of  new  forms  of  urban  data  in  cities,  as  well  as
concepts and methods of spatial data analysis and visualization.
• Explain  the  risks,  limitations,  and  ethical  implications  relating  to  the  use  of  different
• Develop a data-driven strategy for smart cities.
• Discuss  the  opportunities,  limitations,  and  ethical  implications  of  the  data-driven
strategy for smart cities, as well as potential ways to resolve them.
At the end of module 5 the students will be able to:
• Understand and apply basic project management aspects.
• Understand and apply responsible innovation project approaches for an urban context.
Apply knowledge of key concepts of previous modules.
• Conduct independent research within a team and collaborate in a group.
• Advise students in other project groups and advise project commissioners.
• Develop an understanding of professional responsibility.

column1: Wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte en gezondheid vormt de basis van de medische praktijk in onze westerse samenlevingen. Deze kennis over ziekte is, met het huidige biomedische model als uitgangspunt, van betrekkelijk recente datum: het eind van de 19e eeuw. In dit vak bestuderen studenten deze biomedische kennis, onder meer aan de hand van een aantal in Nederland veel voorkomende gezondheidsproblemen. Aan de hand hiervan zal tegelijkertijd duidelijk worden dat de huidige wetenschappelijke kennis het resultaat is van sociale en culturele factoren. Kennis is dan ook veelal historisch bepaald. Door middel van deze meer (medisch) sociologische visie krijgen studenten inzicht in de ""constructivistische"" zienswijze op wetenschappelijke kennis over gezondheid en ziekte.

Gezondheidsproblemen komen niet in dezelfde mate voor in verschillende bevolkingsgroepen. Zo zijn er verschillen naar geslacht en leeftijd, maar ook naar sociaaleconomische positie en etnische herkomst. Om dit te bestuderen is demografische en epidemiologische basiskennis nodig om gezondheidsproblemen en deze relevante factoren te meten en om de onderlinge relaties vast te stellen.

Bovendien worden basale modellen ter verklaring van dergelijke verschillen in gezondheid geïntroduceerd, evenals modellen ter verklaring van verschillen in het omgaan met ziekte (gezondheidspsychologie) en in het zoeken van hulp. Een belangrijke factor hierbij zijn de zogenaamde ""lekenopvattingen"" van ziekte en gezondheid. Immers, de wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte wordt ook vandaag niet door alle bevolkingsgroepen in dezelfde mate gedeeld. Inzicht in deze ""lekenopvattingen"" is belangrijk vanwege de invloed op de omgang met ziekte en het zorggebruik, waaronder bijvoorbeeld de therapietrouw.

Uit voorgaande beschrijving wordt duidelijk dat de sociaal medische wetenschappen bestaan uit verschillende disciplines. Studenten maken daarom kennis met de biomedische geneeskunde, (medische) sociologie, demografie, epidemiologie en gezondheidspsychologie.

De beoogde doelstellingen worden bijgebracht aan de hand van hoorcolleges en werkgroepen. In de hoorcolleges worden de basisconcepten, -modellen en relevante theorieën toegelicht. In de werkgroepen worden deze inzichten toegepast aan de hand van een aantal geselecteerde gezondheidsproblemen. Daarbij wordt gekozen voor voorbeelden van uiteenlopende aard: infectieziekten, chronische gezondheidsproblemen en psychische problematiek.
De student kan na het volgen van deze cursus…

column2: • de disciplines binnen Sociaal Medische Wetenschappen (SMW) –biomedische geneeskunde, epidemiologie, demografie, (medische) sociologie en gezondheidspsychologie – in eigen woorden omschrijven
• objectieve en subjectieve gezondheidsmaten van gezondheidsverschillen in eigen woorden omschrijven
• uitleggen wat primaire, secundaire en tertiaire preventie is
• modellen van arts-patiënt relaties (consensusmodel, conflictmodel, onderhandelingsmodel en contractmodel) toepassen op een casus
• de ervaring van ziekte verklaren aan de hand van gezondheidspsychologische theorieën (het stress-copingmodel en het common-sense model)
• gezondheidsgedrag verklaren op basis van het HAPA-model en het Health Belief model
• uitleggen hoe de betekenis van ziekte en gezondheid onderhevig is aan tijd en cultuur
• de verschillende sociologische theorieën van ziekte en gezondheid (functionalisme, symbolisch interactionisme, marxisme, sociaal constructivisme en de labelling theorie) uitleggen

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: When multiple criteria (such as the preferences of different voters) give rise to different orderings of some set of alternatives (such as candidates running for election), the following question arises: how should one aggregate the different orderings into a single ''taking-all-criteria-into-account” ordering of the alternatives? That question is the central question of Social Choice Theory. Answers to the question crucially depend on the type of information that may be used in the aggregation. In the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory, only ordinal information is allowed. In the traditional framework, answers to the central question are constrained by impossibility results such as Arrow’s theorem, which, very roughly, state that no adequate aggregation method exists. In the literature, various ways to escape these impossibility results have been proposed that all involve, in one way or the other, leaving Social Choice Theory’s traditional framework.

An attempt to aggregate individual preferences into “the societal preference” is often described as an attempt to capture “the will of the people”. This illustrates that the (impossibility) results of Social Choice Theory are important for our thinking about representative democracy and, more generally, political representation.

William Riker (1982) was the first to discuss the upshot of SCT’s results for our understanding of democracy. Riker distinguishes between two different conceptions of democracy: Populism and Liberalism. Basically, Riker argued that SCT’s results testify that Populism is an incoherent conception of democracy. Although SCT’s results have no such bearing on Liberalism, the latter is a very minimal conception of democracy-basically, the possibility for the people to replace the powers that be. Riker;s account of the relation between SCT, voting an democracy has elicited various critical responses in the literature which will be traced in the course. Thus, this course is an introduction to Social Choice Theory and a discussion of the relevance of its results for voting systems, democracy and political representation

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column4: 1. Course goals
2.Percentage
3. Intended learning outcomes
4.Percentage

1. The student can name the basic assumptions of the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory, is able to give definitions of its central notions (e.g. preference ordering, preference profile, social ordering, social welfare function) and can explain the relevance of Social Choice Theory for voting theory.
To have thorough insight into the cohesion of a number of developments in the history of thought, as well as in analytic and continental philosophy.
To be able to think through and interpret philosophical problems in their complexity
To be able to place the knowledge gained in a broader, multidisciplinary context
3.33%

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112061,2023,Social Entrepreneurship,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. P Versari', 'MC Punzi, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Social entrepreneurship is an emerging field of academic study and real-world practice. At its core, social entrepreneurship pertains to the combination of market-based and nonprofit approaches to solve social issues, a feat social entrepreneurs achieve by combining the knowledge and skills used in traditional business with a passionate commitment to having a meaningful and sustainable social impact. By combining insights from the academic literature with real cases and scenarios, the course will introduce students to both theory and practice of social entrepreneurship.

With the exception of week 6 – when students will have to present their group projects - attendance is <u>not mandatory</u> (meaning that no penalties will be assigned for not being able to attend classes). Nonetheless, attendance to all lectures is strongly recommended as part of the final examination will assess also content covered exclusively in class, and direct participation greatly facilitates understanding and sedimentation of the course content.

In any case, the “theoretical” lectures will be recorded and shared on canvas to facilitate content access to those students that cannot attend. Workshops instead will not be recorded: for this reason and for their intrinsically participative nature, it is particularly important to try and attend all workshops.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Recognize the different types of social entrepreneurial action and its characteristics
• Examine the opportunities opened by social entrepreneurship in comparison to normal entrepreneurship
• Evaluate the typical challenges faced by social enterprises
• Design social entrepreneurial models coherently combining commercial and social value creation

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112796,2023,Social Inequalities: An introduction,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. BE French'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What are inequalities? How unequal are societies in which we live? What societal factors have contributed to current states of inequality? In this course, students will develop the tools necessary to critically evaluate such questions. Students gain an overview of many dimensions of inequality in contemporary societies (e.g. wealth, race, gender, space). We will consider dimensions of inequality as inter-related and intersectional. We will look both within societies and across societies to develop an understanding of how inequalities manifests in local and international contexts. We will examine historical trends and utilize interdisciplinary theory and research to discuss the foundations of current inequalities. We will examine how particular inequalities manifest in social institutions like education, health, and criminal justice. Students will learn how researchers are studying these processes in national and international contexts and how to critically reflect on approaches to research. They will learn about the challenges facing scholarship, and participate in key debates that animate contemporary inequalities research.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Explore central concepts through which sociologists investigate inequality.

2. Develop a descriptive and analytical understanding of how class, gender, race and other dimensions of inequality are socially constructed, how they impact interactions, institutional placements, choices, and social policy in contemporary societies.
3. Critically evaluate and explain how dimensions of inequality interact with one another.
4. Apply existing theories and knowledge about inequalities to current and ongoing situations.
5. Learn about and critically reflect upon how these concepts are applied in quantitative, qualitative and mixed-methods empirical research.
After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skills:
1. Be able to critically evaluate academic literature on social inequalities in discussion and writing.
2. Be able to write an academic assignment on patterns, causes and consequences of social inequalities.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116106,2023,Social Innovation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. C Frey - Heger'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Grand challenges, such as climate change, inequality or global migration, are large-scale problems that manifest and need to be addressed across different levels. In this course, we approach an understanding of the potential and the limitations of social innovation to tackle grand challenges. After an introduction to social innovation and grand challenges, we will explore social innovation at the micro-level, social innovation at the meso-level and social innovation at the macro-level and will apply our understanding to different real-world examples, such as Fairphone, the Ocean CleanUp or MPESA. You will analyze the potential, the limitations and the ‘dark sides’ of one social innovation example in a final group poster. This course is for students who are eager to broaden their horizon beyond typical business and management problems and apply their knowledge, analytical and innovative skills to approach the critical challenges of our times, in line with RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change in the world.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completing this course, participants will be able to:

column2: • Describe and recognize grand challenges as manifesting across different levels
• Understand social innovation at different levels and apply such understanding to real-world examples
• Analyse the potential, the limitations and the (unintended) consequences of social innovation in addressing grand challenges
• Design a poster to showcase an analysis and evaluation of a social innovation

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113451,2023,Social Media Data Analytics for Business,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructor:  Dr. C.S. Bos (VU) and Dr. I.D. Lindner (VU)

Social media data analysis is indispensable for businesses of all sizes. Social media provide a platform for customers to share reviews of products, they indicate directions in which the market develops and represent a powerful tool for marketing purposes. This course delves, hands-on, into the wealth of social media data which is readily available, and the manners in which this data can be collected, analyzed, and put to good use for business strategies and research. For this purpose, the course applies the advances in tools available, covering the use of sentiment analysis, basic machine learning and artificial intelligence for extracting the information in social media posts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students will be able to:

column2: • Collect data from social media services such as Twitter using Application Programming Interfaces (API’s) and basic web scrapers,
• clean, visualize and analyse data from various social media services,
• analyse textual comments for sentiments expressed in them,
• understand the basic theory of social media communication networks, and
• identify trends for business strategies and set up models for research and development purposes.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115106,2023,Social Media Marketing,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. FGR De Keyzer', 'dr. YK Nguyen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course offers a combination of theory and practice designed to prepare students for entry level jobs in social media marketing.  We discuss relevant theoretical knowledge about marketing communication, but we also strive to teach you the practical skills which are essential for a career in social media marketing.

In this course, you are invited to challenge the mainstream concepts of marketing communication from a cultural and social perspective. We analyse the strategies that companies employ online in various industries (e.g., fashion, technology, cosmetics) and research new trends such as sustainability, diversity, and brand activism. We also look at narrative aspects of social media advertising such as originality, creativity and storytelling.

The main goal of the course is to meld essential theory with practical application and cover core skills such as strategic planning for social media applications, branding, business communications, and harnessing social media data to yield consumer insights. We achieve this goal through case studies, creative brainstorming, research activities, teamwork and the contribution of social media marketing experts from Adidas, American Express, Aperol/Campari, Unilever, and VanMoof.

This course was previously called ""Social Media Strategies in Business Communication"" but it is still the same course. If you already took CM2274 or CM2074 under the old name, please note that you cannot take this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• ·The cultural and social implications for both marketers and consumers;
• ·The elements of social identity, how individuals build their social identities, and why identities are relevant to marketers;
• ·How some of the world’s leading brands have successfully applied content and digital media into their strategies;
• ·Focus on emerging trends in digital culture, consumer behavior, and data analytics;
• ·Analyze and apply marketing strategies for social media;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In today’s society, social media marketing is ubiquitous. The aim of this course is to provide students with theoretical background as well as initial practical experiences to prepare them for entry level jobs in social media marketing. We discuss relevant theoretical knowledge about (social media) marketing communication, while striving for practical skills to develop social media marketing strategies.  The main goal of the course is, thus, to create a theoretical foundation which can be applied to case studies and examples.In this course, students are invited to challenge the mainstream concepts of marketing communication from different perspectives. Current strategies that companies employ online in various industries (e.g., fashion, technology, cosmetics) will be used as examples of theory. Moreover, research on new trends such as sustainability, diversity, and brand activism will be discussed.

The main goal of the course is to meld essential theory with practical application and cover core skills such as strategic planning for social media applications, branding, business communications, and harnessing social media data to yield consumer insights.

This course was previously called ""Social Media Strategies in Business Communication"" but it is still the same course. If you already took CM2074 or CM2274 under the old name, please note that you cannot take this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Digitization, convergence and connectivity have enabled organizations in the cultural industries to boost the social aspect of their audience relations; users are not only just recipients of media content, but can participate and create value themselves. This participative culture impacts the way organizations in the creative industries function. But how exactly? The possibilities are endless – audiences can be brand ambassadors and aid in the viral marketing of their cultural products. They can be invited for co-creation projects through social media. They are enabled to take up distribution roles in peer-to-peer networks, create content, comment, review, publish, share, download, upload, remix and communicate by means of social networks such as Instagram, Snapchat, YouTube, TikTok or LinkedIn. Social media also pose challenges for organizations in the creative industries: What if your audience is not engaged? What are the motivations for people to become actively involved? What if your creative product causes a strong reaction on social media? Or how should you tell your story online?

In this research workshop, the use of social media in the creative industries will be our research domain. Students are free to choose their own research topic. By means of qualitative research methods, they explore and analyze a self-chosen topic in more depth. They design and execute their own small-scale empirical research, and report about their findings in the course's peer-reviewed academic journal: the Erasmus Journal of Social Media.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - State-of-the-art theory on the topic of this workshop;
- Current qualitative research designs and methods to examine social media use.
- Design and execute a small-scale empirical research;
- Report about the results of their research both in written and oral form;
- Provide each other with peer feedback throughout the course;
- Critically reflect on the constraints and societal implications of their research;
- Constructively work as part of a team.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This is the first course of the Psychology bachelor programme at Erasmus university Rotterdam. In this course you will familiarize yourself with the organization of the Erasmus university Rotterdam, and with the Psychology bachelor programme in particular. During this first phase of your path towards becoming an academically trained psychologist, you will collaboratively learn in small groups with your fellow students.

We start the Psychology bachelor programme with studying society and people around us. This often touches on everyday occurrences and is the area that encourages you to think about your own behaviour and that of those around you. Through this, you will be introduced to Social psychology. This is an area of psychology that focuses on how people influence each other's behaviour, way of thinking and feelings. You will encounter some of the classic topics in social psychology, such as attribution of behaviour and attitudes. A recurring theme in several of the problems featured is the influence the group can have on the individual. Groups can, for example, have a major impact on our performances and on our willingness to help others. We also adjust our behaviour to suit the group's behaviour and social norms. Social psychology is a subfield that is often perceived as fun and interesting because it is so closely linked to everyday experiences.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>During this course you will work on the following learning goals:

column2: • Acquiring a basic understanding of how the Psychology programme at Erasmus University Rotterdam is organized and what it means to be part of the scientific community.
• Connect with fellow students and acquire basic skills that are needed to learn effectively and collaboratively in groups, such as listening, summarizing, and professional conduct.
• Acquiring a basic understanding of the empirical cycle in scientific research and how to read scientific articles.

• Acquiring a basic understanding of social psychology. More specifically, this will involve a basic knowledge on topics such as helping behaviour, attitudes and persuasion, conformism and obedience, social facilitation and social loafing, person perception, stereotypes and prejudices, friendship and attraction.

column1: This course focuses on the application of qualitative and quantitative research methods in the social sciences, with a particular focus on arts, culture, and the media. The course assignments are centred on interview and survey research designs, however, we will discuss a wide range of quantitative and qualitative research methods, such as quantitative and qualitative content analysis and  participatory observations.

The course furthermore familiarizes students with the full process involved in setting up a research project. During the course, students conduct a qualitative and quantitative research proposal, create research questions, operationalise theoretical concepts and variables, and familiarise themselves with several methods of data collection and analysis. Other course activities involve practical assignments that lead to the development of presentation skills, research designs, and the critical evaluation of research reports.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course aims to familiarize students with the main research designs, methods, and techniques of social science research. It provides students with the necessary theoretical and practical knowledge of qualitative and quantitative research methodologies. It furthermore thoroughly discusses the theoretical and philosophical foundations of the pistemological and ontological approaches prevalent in the social sciences.
After completing this course, the students will be able to:
Draw theoretical and practical conclusions based on their review of the research literature
Present their research reviews and plans in a systematic and clear manner, both orally and in writing.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114688,2023,Social and Cultural History,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. L Green', 'R van Lent, MSc', 'RN Murning']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Social and cultural history are two disciplines in field of history. They arose in the late nineteenth century in reaction to traditional schools of political, military, and diplomatic history. Initially, social history focused on the experiences of ordinary people and aimed to unearth the structural sources of historical change. Cultural history analyzed cultural expression (for instance art and architecture) and collective mentalities.

Since the “cultural turn” of the 1980s, cultural history has been influenced by post-modernism and post-colonialism. The fields of social and cultural history have also affected one another: for instance, social historians may engage in discourse analysis as part of their investigation into people's lived experiences; and cultural historians may examine the ways in which ordinary people challenged social constructs.

This course offers a broad introduction into the historiography, methods, and theories of both disciplines. After an introduction to social and cultural history, we focus on a number of themes, including travel, women, death, carnival, gender, and revolution.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students are introduced to the disciplines of social and cultural history. They are acquainted with the history of both disciplines, they can critically assess works of social and cultural historiography and they can apply main theories and methods of both disciplines in academic papers.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113450,2023,Social and Economic Network Analysis,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructor:  Prof. Dr. B. Heidergott (VU), Dr. I.D. Lindner (VU).

Social and Economic Network Analysis course discusses the complex “connectedness” of social and economic relationships which is found in numerous incarnations: the rapid growth of the world-wide-web, the ease with which communication takes place, the fast spread of news and information as well as it’s impact on opinion formation and our society.

We start with an analytical toolbox of recognizing and analyzing patterns of network data. These tools show how to simplify complexity such as (1) global patterns (degree distributions, path lengths and the small world phenomenon, decomposition of networks), (2) segregation patterns (node types and homophily), (3) local patterns (clustering, transitivity, support) as well as (4) positions in networks (neighborhoods, centrality, influence measures). Next, we will discuss research on network formation and analyze how different model assumptions leave their characteristic footprint on network data. On the one hand, there is the large class of (growing) random networks models which explains a plethora of phenomena (rich-get-richer, small world, social media communication graphs). This class also serves as an important benchmark for identifying non-random properties of networks in which links are formed strategically (business relationships, co-author models). Hybrid models lie in between these two complementary approaches and are able to explain a large class of data (islands-connections model). Finally, we will discuss dynamic implications of the network structure in the context of (1) diffusion through networks (spread of information and diseases, financial contagion) as well as (2) learning and consensus formation on networks (imitation and social influence, wisdom of crowds). Key issues for both classes of dynamics are identifying key actors and their impact on aggregate behavior and beliefs. In particular, these methods allow to analyze the value of individuals in a collectivity (value of players in football teams).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze cursus behandelt de sociologische analyse van instituties en hun uitkomsten. Om precies te zijn wordt dit theoretische raamwerk gebruikt voor het analyseren van arbeidsmarktinstituties en hoe deze de verdeling en de kwaliteit van arbeid beïnvloeden. We gaan daarbij in op vraagstukken rondom werkloosheid, arbeidsmarktsegmentatie, flexibilisering van arbeidsrelaties en werkonzekerheid. Dat betekent dat wij ons richten op individualisering van de arbeidsrelatie en globalisering van arbeidsmarkten en de sociale gevolgen van deze ontwikkelingen.

Terwijl de overheid de arbeidsmarkt reguleert via loonbeleid (zoals het geval is bij minimumlonen), ontslagrecht, socialezekerheidsbeleid, enzovoorts, beïnvloeden werkgeversverenigingen en vakbonden de arbeidsmarkt door onderhandelingsprocessen rondom arbeidsomstandigheden, lonen en beroepsopleidingen, die resulteren in collectieve overeenkomsten. De instituties beschermen werknemers tegen risico’s zoals werkloosheid, ziekte en arbeidsongeschiktheid, armoede en pensioen. Ontwikkelingen als individualisering en globalisering kunnen van invloed zijn op de risico’s en de mate van bescherming die de instituties bieden. Vandaar dat vraagstukken rond arbeidsmarktregulering en sociale risico’s vanuit een dynamisch perspectief worden benaderd – meer specifiek wordt aandacht besteed aan economische, sociale en institutionele ontwikkelingen en hun gevolgen voor de arbeidsmarkt.  De vraag hoe nationale overheden en de verschillende arbeidsmarktpartijen omgaan met die veranderen komt ook aan de orde.

Er wordt in het bijzonder aandacht besteed aan hoe de institutionalisering van de arbeidsmarkt kan verschillen (zoals bijvoorbeeld blijkt uit het gegeven dat de mate waarin en wijze waarop arbeidsmarkten worden gecoördineerd verschilt tussen landen). Belangrijke vragen zijn hoe de verschillen in arrangementen leiden tot verschillen in arbeidsmarktbeleid en hoe dit vervolgens het functioneren en de gevolgen van arbeidsmarkten beïnvloedt.</body>

column2: • Aangeven hoe verzorgingsstaatinstituties en arbeidsmarktinstituties de verdeling en kwaliteit van arbeid vormgeven;
• Reflecteren op de relatie tussen verzorgingsstaatinstituties en economische, sociale en politieke uitkomsten;
• Sociologische theorieën over verzorgingsstaten en arbeidsmarktcoördinatie identificeren;
• Het sociologische raamwerk toepassen teneinde sociaal beleid op het gebied van arbeidsmarkten en de uitkomsten daarvan te analyseren;
• Op een heldere en effectieve wijze schriftelijk verslag doen van resultaten.
