https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112050,2023,Supply Chain Analytics,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. M Tekin'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Supply chains are complex networks of organizations that supply and transform materials and distribute final products and services to customers. Managing a supply chain is a big challenge as well as an opportunity for both manufacturing and service industries. For a well-designed and properly managed supply chain, firms must combine internal and external information in a dynamic fashion. Leveraging analytics proves useful to predict the future and to obtain a competitive advantage. However, there might be some challenges. For example, if the competitor runs a promotion in one period, the customers in the market are likely to stockpile to take advantage of the promotion and this will have an effect on sales of our firm not only for the current period but also for the future periods. Such effects complicate the forecasting process. In this course, we will also discuss econometric models that account for these effects.

This elective course discusses different types of analytics tools to effectively design a successful supply chain. Demand forecasting and inventory management are two fundamental topics of supply chain analysis. In terms of demand forecasting, students will learn how to accurately predict the number of items to be sold next week/month/year based on historical sales data. With the goal of forecasting the future demand, the mathematical and econometrics tools (i.e. time series analysis) will prove useful. Once demand is estimated accurately, the next step is inventory management. In this section, several replenishment methods will be studied. Finally, when capacity is limited, revenue management models have proven effective to match supply with demand. The course will also touch upon the essentials of revenue management techniques for service industries.

The course adopts modern forecasting and machine learning methods to improve the performance of a supply chain while reducing the total cost. Students will have hands-on experience on real life applications of supply chain analytics.

Attendance is not compulsory and does not directly affect the total grade. However, as the class discussion contributes to your learning experience, attending the class sessions is strongly encouraged.

All lectures and tutorials will be recorded. The recordings will be made available on Canvas right after the class so that in case you cannot attend the session, you can view it whenever it is suitable for you.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Examine and improve the supply chain operations such as flow of materials through a network of suppliers, manufacturers, distributors and retailers
• Conduct demand forecasting using time series methods and econometric models
• Be familiar with managing uncertainty in supply chains
• Understand tradeoffs to manage inventories in real world
• Understand and apply revenue management models and principles

• Apply analytical tools and models for effective solutions to problems in managing a supply chain using the R programming language (via tutorials) and address the analytical challenges arising in supply chains
• Provide and justify recommendations to improve supply chain operations in the form of (online) presentations and written reports

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113997,2023,Supply Chain Decision Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. S Lemmens', 'E Aghamohammadzadeh, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Success in a complex supply chain environment depends on our ability to make good decisions. This requires a systematic, data-driven, and fact-based approach to decision-making and problem analysis. The same philosophy is also at the heart of scientific research. This course introduces a variety of tools for business analytics and optimization modeling. You will explore research that aims to solve decision problems in supply chain management. Moreover, this course teaches skills and the methodological background necessary for your thesis project, which starts in January.
• Tools: Excel Solver and IBM ILOG CPLEX

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Formulate complex supply chain decision problems as optimization models
• Implement and solve optimization models in Excel Solver
• Implement and solve optimization models in IBM ILOG CPLEX
• Interpret the solution of optimization models and discuss relevance to practice

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113989,2023,Supply Chain Fundamentals,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. Q Kong'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course is a mix of lectures, case studies, and games. The lectures are meant to explain supply chain models and concepts making use of both qualitative and quantitative methods. Qualitative methods involve theoretical frameworks, conceptual analysis, and evaluation of solution strategies whereas quantitative methods involve mathematical analysis, probability theory and basic concepts of microeconomics. Case studies depict a business scenario at a certain existing company; in which complex supply chain management decisions need to be taken. The situation is often partly described from the perspective of one of the key players in the decision–making process; furthermore, a certain degree of urgency is present as well. A teaching case requires very thorough preparation by the participant. Finally, students will be required to play game in a supply chain context, which will involve strategic and operational decisions.
To pass this core course, a participant needs to:

column2: • Individual and group assignments (including game performance and reports) (40% of the final grade);
• Take a written exam (60% of the final grade).
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Supply chain management has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, given the current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. This core course is intended for students with a strong interest in understanding logistics and operations – in either manufacturing or service industries – and the role supply chains and supply chain operations can play in business. The course will be particularly valuable for those who see their careers in operations/supply chain over the coming decade, or who see themselves consulting in operations/supply chain for client businesses. The course objectives are to:

column2: • Make you conversant in the language of supply chain management and expand your confidence in these area
• Allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations

• Analyze the underlying issues and trade-offs between the sourcing of raw materials, the manufacturing, storage, and transportation of products and the services required to fulfill customer expectations and the metrics of the firm
• Provide you with quantitative and qualitative tools to identify, analyze and manage supply chain operations and issues
• Analyze supply chains and supply chain operations to identify problems and improvement opportunities
• Recommend and initiate supply chain improvement actions and projects
• Enhance your team working and project management skills

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115285,2023,Supply Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Becker-Peth', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Companies have over time specialized in a very limited number of business activities which they consider to be their core business. By doing so, they have been able to greatly increase their expertise, innovative capabilities and process efficiency. Companies have subsequently located their operations in regions that are most suitable in terms of natural resources, labor (either cheap or high grade), sales markets etc. As a consequence, a long chain of companies is involved in the manufacturing of products. These companies have limited insight into each other’s operations, and are often dispersed around the world. Such a situation requires that the chain of companies is effectively managed otherwise processes would falter, customers would have to be disappointed, and costs would surge. Therefore, supply chain management is vital to companies that operate in such chains. Proper planning and managing of the supply chain can make the difference between a successful business and an outright failure.

Progress in information technology has contributed to both the increasing need and opportunities for improved supply chain management. With IT, companies in a supply chain can be connected in real-time, which allows for efficient and effective sharing of information.

The course program presents cases of real-world situations calling for appropriate state-of-the-art models and solution methods for the design, planning, control and improvement of supply chain operations.
The course Supply Chain Management builds on the knowledge obtained in the course Operations Management offered in Bachelor 1.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Goal 1: - identify and use the main concepts and terminology in the domain of supply chain management
• Goal 2: - select and use the appropriate instruments and tools to construct a supply chain management solution for a given situation
• Goal 3: - identify and describe the needed design features of the supply chain
• Goal 4: - understand and apply different forecasting techniques
• Goal 5: - recognize and use the different inventory replenishment strategies to control inventory levels
• Goal 6: - clarify and leverage the value of information sharing as assisted by information technology for the integrated supply chain
• Goal 7: - describe and choose the correct purchasing and sourcing strategy dependent on the features of a supply chain

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116965,2023,Supply Chain Simulation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. GG Loke'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Modern supply chain management involves decision making in uncertain, dynamic, and complex environments. This course focuses on the use of simulation techniques to make better supply chain decisions under such conditions. In particular, we shall examine discrete event simulations. For that purpose, the course combines relevant theoretical knowledge with application of simulation techniques to model real-life supply chains using computer models. These models serve as a safe playground to study and evaluate supply chain decision making, allowing us to gain essential insights into how supply chain performance may be improved.

The course is divided into (mandatory) lectures in which students will learn the theoretical basics, and (mandatory) workshops, where students will learn how to build simulation models in Arena. The grade is based on three individual assignments and one group assignment. The lab sessions give students the opportunity to ask questions on the assignments.
The assignment sessions are not mandatory; students who do not require any help for the assignments do not need to be present. No new material will also be taught during the assignment sessions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and apply the key concepts of discrete event simulations
• Analyze input data for use in a simulation model
• Run experiments with a simulation model, and draw conclusions on the process modelled
• Understand the concept of decision making under uncertainty
• Gain insight into how the quality of a solution is affected by unknown factors and by an unknown future

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116963,2023,Supply chain forecasting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J van Dalen', 'dr. R Kuik']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The forecasting of product demand, new product success, risk events, prices, costs and capacity dynamics is an important activity in every day decision making in companies throughout the supply chain. It directly affects inventory management, procurement and production decisions, logistics resources and financial planning, and thus has a strong impact on the performance of individual companies, as well as that of a supply chain as a whole. The Supply Chain Forecasting elective is about acquiring a robust understanding of common and advanced forecasting methods used in practice, and about training programming skills to apply these methods in practical situations.

column2: • Machine learning techniques, e.g., decision trees, random forests, gradient boosting; and ensemble forecasting
• Forecasting intermittent demand, and the relation between forecasting and inventory management
• Judgmental forecasting, and the influence of judgmental adjustments on forecast performance
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The learning objectives of this course are:

column2: • Understand and apply the common forecasting and analytics methods used in business, both in terms of assumptions and operation

• Ability to apply forecasting and analytics in programming, involving data processing, selection and application of relevant analytical functions, collect and present the outcomes of analyses; solve non-trivial statistical problems using a programming language and environment, e.g., R and RStudio
• Design and perform a scientific study aimed at answering a practical, forecasting-oriented question, report outcomes in solid writing and convincing presentation
• Demonstrate the ability to effectively communicate ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders.
• Critically reflect on ethical ramifications of data collection, team work and proposed implementations of analytical findings.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115297,2023,Supply chain management,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. S Lemmens', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Bedrijven zijn zich in toenemende mate gaan specialiseren op een beperkt aantal kernactiviteiten (de zogenaamde ‘core business’). Door deze specialisatie zijn bedrijven in staat om op hun deelgebied veel kennis op te bouwen, innovatieve producten te ontwikkelen en efficiënt te werken. Bedrijven vestigen zich op locaties die voor hun specialisme het meest geschikt zijn. Dit kan zijn vanwege de beschikbaarheid van grondstoffen, goedkope of juist hoogwaardige arbeidskrachten, belangrijke afzetmarkten, etc. Als gevolg van deze specialisatie is een lange keten van bedrijven betrokken bij de fabricage van een eindproduct. Bedrijven die vaak een beperkt inzicht hebben in elkaars activiteiten en die verspreid over de hele wereld kunnen zitten. Een dergelijke situatie vereist dat de keten van bedrijven goed gemanaged wordt omdat anders de processen vastlopen, klanten teleurgesteld moeten worden en kosten hoog oplopen. Supply chain management is daarom van cruciaal belang voor bedrijven die zich in dergelijke ketens bevinden. Het plannen en managen van de supply chain kan het verschil maken tussen een succesvol bedrijf en een complete mislukking.

De vooruitgang in informatietechnologie heeft bijgedragen aan zowel de stijgende behoefte als aan de toenemende kansen voor een verbeterd supply chain management. Met behulp van IT kunnen bedrijven hun supply chain koppelen aan real-time informatie en kan op een effectieve en efficiënte manier kennis gedeeld worden.
In dit vak worden verscheidene bedrijfscases gepresenteerd die vragen om state-of-the-art modellen en oplossingsmethoden voor ontwerp, planning, beheersing en verbetering van supply chains.

Dit vak moedigt studenten aan niet alleen de vereiste kennis te vergaren, maar ook om een kritische houding te verwerven ten aanzien van de positie van bedrijven in relatie tot de verschillende strategische en operationele keuzes gerelateerd aan de supply chain.
§  de student de taal van supply chain management te laten begrijpen en gebruiken;
§  de student inzicht te geven in de rol die supply chain management speelt in de bedrijfsstrategie en de prestaties van de organisatie;
§  de student kritisch te laten kijken en denken over zowel supply chain management als andere aspecten van het managen van een organisatie;
§  de student te voorzien van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve tools om hem in staat te stellen eenvoudige supply chain management vraagstukken te identificeren, analyseren en op te lossen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Doel 01: - de belangrijkste concepten en terminologie uit het supply chain management vakgebied te benoemen en te gebruiken;
• Doel 02: - de juiste instrumenten en methoden te kiezen en te gebruiken om een supply chain management oplossing te genereren voor een bepaald probleem;
• Doel 03: - de ontwerpkenmerken van de supply chain te benoemen en uit te leggen;
• Doel 04: - de verschillende voorspellingsmethoden in supply chain management toe te passen;
• Doel 05: - de verschillende voorraadbestelstrategieën te herkennen en te gebruiken om voorraadniveaus te beheersen;
• Doel 06: - de waarde van informatiedeling duidelijk te maken en te gebruiken, ondersteund door informatie technologie voor de geïntegreerde supply chain;
• Doel 07: - de juiste inkoop- en sourcingstrategieën te beschrijven en te kiezen afhankelijk van de kenmerken van een supply chain;
• Doel 08: - de fysieke distributie in een supply chain in te richten en het transport hierop aan te passen;
• Doel 09: - de verschillende (strategische) samenwerkingsvormen te benoemen tussen partijen in een supply chain en de bijbehorende risico’s te identificeren en te reduceren;
• Doel 10: - echte bedrijfscases te analyseren en hiervoor gepaste supply chain oplossingen te ontwikkelen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114825,2023,Surveillance and Societies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. D Trottier'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Surveillance denotes the collection of personal information for purposes of control. It is a primary organising logic among states and organisations, but also activists and other individuals. Surveillance involves the use of emerging technologies, as well as longstanding forms of management and governance, in order to make the social world knowable and assert a particular social order.

This course aims to situate surveillance practices in diverse institutions, in order to recognise their social, cultural and communicative purpose in contemporary societies. This course treats surveillance as a topic that garners public concern, with the goal of contributing to theoretical and empirical accounts to these understandings.

Students will consider surveillance practices across institutional and cultural contexts. This will involve applying concepts and assumptions to a range of developments. Each week addresses a particular context in which surveillance occurs, and bridges digitally mediated with embodied practices. Students will participate in and occasionally lead discussions on particular forms of surveillance, and their social, cultural, informational and ethical dimensions and implications.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - Foundational conceptual frameworks and theoretical perspectives about surveillance practices across social contexts
- Historically and culturally situated accounts of information technologies
- Apply concepts and empirical insights about surveillance practices to relevant contexts, notably linking emerging cases with historic precedents
- Appraise public discourses in order to interpret how surveillance practices are shaped and normalised
- Critically engage with surveillance studies scholarship to consider its relevance to digital media and communication studies</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116742,2023,Survival Analysis (Module III),Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['A. Pires Ferreira', 'prof. dr. D. Rizopoulos', 'prof. dr. ir. H. Boersma']",,"Inhoud

column1: Prerequisite Research Master students: Research Master students need to have done both Biostatistics I (MEP-CK020) and Module II (R course, PHDCO-014) before participating in Module III.
Prerequisite other participants: Participants need to have done both Module I (Introduction to Biostatistics, PHDCO-013) and Module II (R course, PHDCO-014) before participating in Module III.

This course presents methods for the statistical analysis of time-to-event data, also known as survival data. The course begins by explaining the unique features of this data that invalidate the use of standard statistical tools. Then, alternative descriptive and inferential analysis techniques are introduced, including the Kaplan-Meier estimator, the log-rank test for censored data, and the Cox proportional hazards model. Finally, the course closes by presenting the stratified Cox model and how to handle competing risks.
During the course, the participants will learn to use R to perform survival analysis and interpret the obtained results correctly.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to the start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

column2: • Identify the challenges in analyzing time-to-event data
• Know which statistical techniques and tests to use that account for censoring
• Know for what type of model to use depending on the research questions
• Be able to fit regression models in R, correctly interpret the output
3.5 days, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday morning
13:30-16:30: Self-study, perform analysis in R and interpret the results

column1: Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course
During the course, you need to register your attendance digitally through Academy Attendance.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116776,2023,Sustainability Accounting and Reporting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J Choi, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In many countries and industries, sustainability accounting is now acknowledged as an essential process of business operation where companies develop measures for their environmental, social, and governance performances; ensure their reliability; report to stakeholders; and assist managers in making critical decisions for their companies and society. However, adopting and implementing such a complex managerial system has become more and more challenging as the demand from stakeholders for responsible business has grown substantially during the past decades. This course offers an overview of managerial processes involved in sustainability accounting with a focus on sustainability reporting. Students will learn basic concepts, theories and practices and be given opportunities to apply their knowledge and critical thinking to evaluating sustainability reports and standards.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Recognize the distinguishable processes through which sustainability is measured, assured, and reported
• Examine various types of sustainability measurement/reporting standards
• Explain the typical challenges faced by companies regarding sustainability accounting

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114589,2023,Sustainability Ethics & Sustainable Behaviour,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MJJ Wubben', 'prof.dr. MH van Dijke']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With the global population growing to 9.7 billion people, the World Business Council for Sustainable Development forecasts that if organizations do not drastically revise their way of doing business, humanity will be consuming the ecological resources of 2.3 earths in 2050. To avert the disaster that would ensue, organizations need to foster sustainable development by helping to meet the needs of the present generation without compromising the needs of future generations. This requires a focus not only on economic, but also on environmental and social performance.

Such a focus is not self-evident. Think of high-profile scandals such as the Enron, Lehman Brothers, and Volkswagen debacles. The economic, social, and environmental consequences of such drastic, moral transgressions may be so profound that they potentially nullify any sustainable development. Yet even for the many organizational members—CEOs and employees alike—that do embrace sustainability, dilemmas and challenges arise: When should environmental outcomes prevail over social outcomes? How much should we rely on technological solutions? How can we and our stakeholders bridge the gap between good intentions and good behavior? These issues show that sustainability and ethics go hand in hand, and that both present and future business leaders need to embody both.

This course offers a broad, psychological and philosophical perspective on sustainable, moral behaviour in business. How can such behaviour be encouraged in employees, in CEOs, in organizations as a whole, and in their stakeholders? Conversely, how can unsustainable, immoral behaviour be averted? Such questions will be discussed in the context of, among others, normative stakeholder theory, greenwashing, green consumerism, social dilemmas, environmental ethics, and moral development and sustainable values in individuals and organizations.

In line with the first Intended Learning Outcome of the Msc programme, this course fosters in-depth and systematic knowledge about managing for sustainability by adopting both a descriptive and a normative approach, focusing both on theory and practice. The lectures are meant to not only give you topical insights from rigorous, empirical research, but also to help you grow as a moral manager who contributes to making companies more sustainable. Through various discussions in the lectures and the individual and group assignments, students learn to design sound sustainability management research projects (Intended Learning Outcome 2) and develop their solution-based skills and attitude to deal with challenges of sustainability management (Intended Learning Outcome 3).
The course features a few asynchronous videos, but all lectures, consultation sessions and presentations sessions take place on campus.

All lectures except the introduction lecture and guest lecture will be taught twice: Once in the morning to one half of the class, and once in the afternoon to the other half of the class. Missing lectures is problematic for completing the course and achieving the learning goals. Attendance is strongly recommended for ALL lectures, including the guest lecture.

To help you with the team project, there are two 20-minute consultation sessions for each team. Students can make teams and sign up for the consultation sessions at the end of Lecture 1. Teams can choose any open timeslot to register for the consultation sessions, so you do not need to be available for the entire day. It is recommended, though not mandatory, for all team members to visit the consultation sessions.
The presentation sessions are mandatory. They are scheduled throughout the day and take no more than two hours.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To understand the ways in which sustainability and morality are intertwined
• To understand what drives sustainable, moral behaviour in employees, in CEOs, and in organizations as a whole
• To further develop self-awareness of your moral development and sustainable values
• To translate empirical research and theory on sustainability and business ethics into real-world interventions

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114591,2023,Sustainability Grand Challenges,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. TJF Bauwens'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course focuses on the sustainability grand challenges of our times. Sustainability grand challenges can refer to environmental or ecological problems as well as social problems. Examples include climate change, land degradation and natural disasters or global displacement, poverty, and inequality. Grand challenges are global problems that require combined efforts and new innovative approaches to better understand, harness, and tackle them.

In this course, you will collaborate to analyze a sustainability grand challenge and formulate “solutions” by engaging multiple partners and by thinking out-of-the-box. Specifically, you work together to create a novel and (commercially) viable solution to a real-world grand challenge. The main learning goal of this course is to understand and harness a sustainability grand challenge.

You will work individually as well as in teams and under significant time pressure to analyze the grand challenge and formulate a credible and feasible “solution.” You will individually demonstrate your understanding of the grand challenge with an individual essay and jointly develop and assess a solution in a group report. At the end of the course, using the time-restricted and context-sensitive format of a pitch to practice effectively structuring and delivering your message, you will present the solution in the group report to a multi-stakeholder jury.

As you will be tackling a live business case, by following interactive workshops, interviewing real-life stakeholders and coming up with a solution within a limited timeframe, your learning has an important experiential and possibly a transformative component, not unlike what may await you in your future career. To further capitalize on this experience, you will also work on a reflection portfolio that helps you to capture your unique needs, skills, and improvements as you and your team quickly become relative experts on the grand challenge by formulating creative solutions that can make a real-world impact.
When you enter the on-campus or online classroom, we enter into an implicit agreement. We agree to impart knowledge and to do so in a well-prepared, engaging way.

Thus, participants should attend and actively participate in the classes, are expected to engage in in-class discussions, ask questions to speakers and guest lecturers, and demonstrate involvement with the in-class exercises and workshops.

Attendance is strongly recommended for all sessions, both on campus and online, to be able to successfully pass the course. It is important to be able to contribute to the group project, for which everybody is expected to take equal responsibility. On-campus attendance is mandatory for the final pitching session to the multi-stakeholder jury, which is graded as pass or fail.
Be present a few minutes prior to the start of each session, so that the class starts on time.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Evaluate the sustainability grand challenge using different theoretical frameworks on wicked problems, temporality, and scale
• Assess and reflect on personal needs, skills, and improvements
• Jointly analyze the stakeholders related to the sustainability grand challenge
• Jointly synthesize a systems map representing the sustainability grand challenge
• Jointly develop a solution to harness the sustainability grand challenge
• Jointly evaluate the viability of the developed solution
• Jointly deliver a convincing pitch suitable for the boardroom

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111379,2023,Sustainability Transitions,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['AM Mockovcakova', 'dr. AR Vasques', 'dr. MD Werner', 'dr.ir. AV Moiseeva', 'N van Roessel, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This minor offers students ways to explore different academic and disciplinary perspectives on persistent sustainability challenges and how they can be analysed. We offer understanding of the role of law, business, economics, philosophy and governance to understand how we can enact transformative change for a sustainable society. Students will work in small interdisciplinary teams on a concrete sustainability transition and will develop an intervention that will contribute to a more sustainable society.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114625,2023,Sustainability in the Visual Arts and Crafts,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['E Naclerio', 'O Vincent']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course provides an introduction to and application of key concepts and developments in thinking about sustainability in contemporary societies and cities, covering environmental, social and economic dimensions. From the early conceptualizations of sustainable development to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, from the Anthropocene to the climate crisis, from the doughnut and circular economy to green growth and greenwashing – we will start by reviewing and critically assessing the contribution of different concepts to contemporary societal challenges. Then we will apply these concepts to an exploration of sustainable practices in the fields of contemporary visual arts and crafts, mapping out key developments in production, consumption and communication. We will critically assess the potential of small-scale urban making and crafts to offer solutions for sustainable forms of production and consumption practices, exploring opportunities and potential pitfalls. Moreover, we will appraise the role that the visual arts can play in addressing sustainability topics, and we will explore what (un)sustainable practices can occur in the (visual) arts world. By the end of this course, students will have the ability to reproduce and critically discuss some of the most influential concepts and approaches to sustainable development in contemporary visual arts and crafts</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course offers an introduction to notions and debates around sustainability in contemporary societies and applies these notions to an exploration of sustainable practices in crafts and the visual arts. By the end of this course, students will have the ability to:

column2: • Recognize and explain central concepts and debates in contemporary theoretical and policy approaches to sustainability
• Analyse key sustainability trends in the production, consumption and communication practices, notably in the fields of the visual arts and crafts
• Critically assess sustainability concepts and apply them to case studies in the fields of contemporary visual arts and crafts.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116979,2023,Sustainable Care Systems,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['MV Tietschert'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared climate change as “the single biggest health threat facing humanity”, caused by increased mean temperature of the atmosphere and the oceans, rising sea level, ocean acidification, and more frequent and more devastating extreme weather events (e.g., floods, storms, wildfires, drought). These aspects of climate change have profound impacts on our health. The severity of impact however depends on the intersection of physical threads, the exposure to these threads, the vulnerability of individuals and communities and the capacity to prepare for, manage, and recover from extreme events. The relative impact of climate change is thus contingent on the extent to which societies are prepared to respond to and manage the implications of climate change. This presents a crucial task and opportunity for healthcare systems and organizations, which are both contributors to and susceptible to climate change.

This interdependence between human actions and climate change and its impact on health lead to a new perspective on health called planetary health. The Rockefeller Foundation–Lancet Commission defines Planetary Health as “the achievement of the highest attainable standard of health, wellbeing, and equity worldwide through judicious attention to the human systems—political, economic, and social—that shape the future of humanity and the Earth's natural systems that define the safe environmental limits within which humanity can flourish.” In other words, planetary health encompasses the health of human civilisation and the state of the natural systems on which it depends. Planetary health is a practice-oriented approach that provides a framework for healthcare organizations to adjust to and respond adequately to the challenges posed by climate change by building resilience. According to the WHO, Climate resilient healthcare systems are those that are “capable to anticipate, respond to, cope with, recover from and adapt to climate-related shocks and stress, so as to bring sustained improvements in population health, despite an unstable climate”. Planetary health emphasizes the importance of a coordinated, transdisciplinary approach across many organizations of health systems.

This course provides a comprehensive exploration on what is needed to build climate resilient, sustainable health systems. Students will learn about planetary health and its implications and opportunities for healthcare systems to respond to climate change. Specifically, students will explore the antecedents of planetary health, the opportunities for achieving gains in health, the threats and opportunities for healthcare systems to respond adequately to climate changes, and the requirements for health system reforms to reduce threats and translate opportunities including system thinking and transdisciplinary approaches for improving planetary health and health system resilience.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can reflect critically on recent academic evidence related to climate change, the concept of planetary health and implications for health and healthcare systems.
• Students can adopt a planetary health lens to identify threats and opportunities for health gains and health system resilience caused by climate change.
• Students can adopt a system thinking lens to disentangle the problems and develop adequate solutions to developing climate resilient healthcare systems.
• Students can present their ideas for health system improvement in convincing ways that are grounded in academic knowledge.

• Students will be able to analyze complex problems using conceptual and analytical models and to develop solutions for healthcare systems and its organizations based on academically grounded, structured approaches.
• Students will be able to collaborate with various stakeholders in transdisciplinary ways for developing resilient, sustainable health systems.
• Students will be able to pinpoint implications of their solutions by incorporating different disciplinary views that bridge academy, policy and practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Sustainable development in historical perspective is a course that combines Applied History, development theory and policy analysis to assess the way in which international politics seeks to address issues of social and economic development in the contemporary world. While there certainly is an overlap, politicians and economists, both between and among themselves, differ on the definition and scope of the term sustainable development. And more importantly, the Development Goals that have come to define the global political consensus in this regard are by no means uncontested and certainly are not equal to actual policies that deliver.

In this course we start from the UN’s seventeen Sustainable Development Goals (previously eight Millennial Goals) and examine the reasons behind differentiated views on their nature, number, and scope. We then explore the essential notions of what constitutes Applied History and use the state of knowledge on comparative historical development to assess the institutional preconditions, driving forces and complexities of the acceleration in economic and social development over the last two centuries. Combining these insights with the basics of development theory and political economy, we ask how these can play a role in informing policy. The seminars close by assessing policies aimed at realizing Development Goals from the viewpoint of actual outcomes, external effects, mutual trade-offs, and local conditions and interests that differ between groups and nations. Drawing upon the seminars and a preceding presentation, students are finally required to write a review paper on a relevant academic debate of their choice.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Following this course, students will be able to:
- Understand and participate in academic and public political debate on sustainable development.

- Use the state of knowledge on comparative historical economic development and basic theory of economic development and social choice to inform public policy on the drivers, mechanisms and complexities of economic development.
- Critically assess policies aimed at realizing Development Goals from the viewpoint of actual policy outcomes, external effects, trade-offs between goals and differential interests and conditions.
- Write a review paper on an academic debate that is of relevance to questions of public policy on socio-economic issues.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides insight in the sustainability challenges and the link to finance. The main task of the financial system is to allocate funding to its most productive use. Traditional finance focuses on financial return and regards the financial sector as separate from the society of which it is part and the environment in which it is embedded. By contrast, sustainable finance considers financial, social, and environmental returns in combination and shows how finance can accelerate the transition to a low-carbon, inclusive economy.

The course reviews evidence that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors matter and explains in detail how to incorporate these in company strategies and business models, equity investing, bond investing, and bank lending. The course examines the financial instruments and techniques that can be applied in the context of evolving climate policies (and other sustainability policies). The tools will be applied in a group assignment on the valuation of a company based on sustainability factors.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and apply the impact of ESG factors on valuation and pricing for investing and lending
• Link sustainability with the role of finance professional as steward
• Explain the novel concept of integrated value based on the fundamental corporate finance framework and relate it to the traditional concepts of private and social value
• Explain the dynamics and risks of transition management for the financial sector
• Critically review the impact of organisations and investors on SDGs

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116983,2023,Sustainable Healthcare Organizations,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. J Weenink', 'prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Healthcare organizations can have various impacts on the environment and on biodiversity due to their operational activities and the delivery of health services. These impacts include energy consumption, water usage, waste generation, chemical and pharmaceutical pollution, consumption of abiotic resources, infrastructure and land use, and transportation. To address these environmental impacts, healthcare organizations need to adopt sustainable practices and policies, promote energy efficiency, implement waste management strategies, adopt green building designs, engage in responsible procurement, and consider the lifecycle environmental impacts of their operations.

This course offers a comprehensive exploration of sustainability in healthcare organizations, focusing on the assessment and reduction of environmental impact. Students will learn methods and strategies for measuring and reducing the environmental impact of healthcare services. The course also examines the perspectives of different stakeholders and the role of stakeholder engagement in driving sustainable change within healthcare organizations. Additionally, students will explore the relationship between sustainability and other aspects of care, such as quality, accessibility, and costs, and learn to critically reflect on the potential trade-offs and synergies between sustainability and these other aspects.

Through an interdisciplinary approach, students will develop the necessary knowledge, skills, and critical thinking abilities to understand and address the complex challenges associated with sustainability in the healthcare sector. By the end of the course, students will be equipped with innovative approaches and a critical mindset to drive positive change and promote sustainable practices in healthcare.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the factors contributing to the environmental impact of healthcare organizations.
• Can apply methods and strategies for assessing and reducing the environmental impact of a health service.
• Can critically reflect on the strengths and limitations of methods and frameworks for assessing and improving the sustainability of health services.
• Can critically reflect on the relationship between sustainability and quality, accessibility, and costs in healthcare.
• Can critically reflect on how to organize sustainable healthcare improvement, considering the perspectives of different stakeholders.
• Can provide advice to healthcare organizations on improving their sustainability.
• Can collaborate effectively in a group project.

column1: The Sustainable and Equitable Food Strategies (SEFS) course aims at applying a transdisciplinary approach to answer wicked problems in the global food sector, focusing on management studies, and introducing some basic concepts of environmental sciences and social sciences. The ultimate goal is making management studies in the food sector more transformative by tackling both personal and global political aspects. The course offers an overview of the food system by investigating and exploring 3 levels of interaction: Macro (society and environment), Meso (companies) and Micro (individual consumers).

At the end, students will understand the interactions between the actors of the ""global food chain"" (such as governments, international institutions, local market/producers, the big food corporations and supermarket chains) that shape our food system. Sustainability in the food sector will be further analysed from the perspective of the United Nation’s Sustainability Goals.

The course draws on using a problem-oriented project-work approach by implementing action learning techniques, as well as personal essays and business case assessments, with a particular focus on the political economy of food. Major themes include the sustainable and equitable properties of food, transformations in the food industry and global regulations. Particular attention will be dedicated to the sustainability of food that will be tackled from different angles, such as international dietary guidelines, the environmental impact of food production (e.g. organic vs industrial food; processed/non processed food; animal based vs plant-based food) and societal drawbacks (i.e. food security and food waste management). In order to realize this ambition, the course will use a do-it-yourself (DIY) approach by collaborating with the Erasmus Food Lab for cooking workshops where all the theoretical knowledge will be put into practice.

Attendance of lectures and practical activities is mandatory. Only TWO absences are allowed throughout the course. With THREE absences the student will lose 10% of the final grade. With FOUR or more absences the student will fail the course. In case of force majeure (e.g., illness) an exception can be made, but a documented proof (e.g., doctor’s note) is needed. Please note that attendance to the final presentation is mandatory and cannot be skipped.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyse the global and local aspects of food production and consumption from a transformative approach
• Develop business and management strategies in order to create a positive impact for a healthy, sustainable and equitable food system

• Apply a self-inquiry in the form of a daily food journal and evaluate individual and institutional actions and behaviour against a framework for sustainable and responsible food practices in interaction with food businesses and organizations
• Foster a reflexive and creative attitude to transfer self-gathered knowledge and skills to others
• Create professional collaboration to promote sustainability within organizations and towards society

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116770,2023,Sustainable business models,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. TA Alade'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Organizations demand business models that are sustainable, especially in addressing societal sustainability issues and wicked problems in society. However, the leadership and competencies to achieve this important need are limited and create a gap for you to fill. Therefore, the overall goal of this course is to enable you to develop a self-employable mindset and competent leadership, in the creation of impact-driven sustainable business models for organizations. Having this unique knowledge and how it is applied to make organizations more sustainable and impactful, gives you a strong competitive edge in the job market, to add value to diverse organizations in need of sustainable business models. Thereby delivering value to organizations as their employee or as a self-employed sustainable business model consultant.

“A sustainable business model describes, analyses, manages, and communicates (i) a company’s sustainable value proposition to its customers, and all other stakeholders, (ii) how it creates and delivers this value, (iii) and how it captures economic value while maintaining or regenerating natural, social, and economic capital beyond its organizational boundaries.” (Schaltegger et al., 2016, p. 6). ""The starting point for the Sustainable Business Model is the recognition that business models not only offer a new way of studying the relationships between companies and their natural, social, and economic environment (Marcus et al., 2010; Stubbs and Cocklin, 2008) but also alternative and potentially more sustainable ways of designing business architectures within this environment"" (Upward and Jones, 2016).

This course will start with the application of theories of sustainable business models to different sectors of the economy. After your in-depth understanding and application of these theories, you will learn how to evaluate the demands of sustainable business model designs, considering the most common patterns within the forty-five pattern groups. Such as some pattern groups by F. Lüdeke-Freund et al. (2018) in Table 1 below.

The next learning objective involves the collaboration with four organizations to evaluate their already existing business models and in groups create an impact-driven sustainable business model for an organizational business case. This aspect shows how you can make an already existing business model of an organization more sustainable and impactful to society. The four organizations will visit us on campus, during the early stages of the course to present their sustainable business model. Then return towards the end of the course to listen to your group presentations on the re-designed business models, with the integration of more sustainable and impactful business models.

The last part of the course entails how you can reflect on your own personal competencies to provide leadership in sustainable business model design. Here the Inner development goals will be used, considering its components of being, thinking, relating, collaborating, and acting. To wrap up the course we shall be playing the SDG game, to deepen our reflection capabilities on the use of SDGs for a sustainable business model.

Attendance in the classes is mandatory. If you are sick, or you have a personal situation that requires you to be away from class, send an explanatory e-mail in advance to the course coordinator (Taslim Alade; alade@rsm.nl ). One excused absence will be accepted. More than one absence results in the deduction of 5% for each absence from your final grade of the course, unless you have special circumstances. If you have a special circumstance, we are very willing to support you to finish the course as required.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Apply theories of sustainable business models to different sectors
• Evaluate the demands of sustainable business model patterns
• Create an impact driven sustainable business model for an organizational business case
• Reflect on personal competencies to provide leadership in sustainable business model design

column1: <body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Introduce key concepts and problems in the philosophy of science.
• Develop the capacity of students to critically evaluate concepts and approaches in management science with regards to fundamental problems in the philosophy of science.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Any research will have to rely on a review of previous (academic) literature, but the specific motivations for and form of this literature review may vary. In its most elementary form, a literature review is meant to familiarize the researcher with the field of study, as part of the overall research process – as in the case of a PhD project. A literature review can also be part of a specific study, to help motivate and position the new study and its intended contributions. Lastly, a review of literature can in itself be a specific study and publication, to assess the state of the field and help direct future research.

In this brief course, we start from these different purposes of literature reviews and identify a variety of literature reviews, and their key ingredients and strengths and weaknesses. Understanding the different types of reviews and the critical choices involved will help you not only in choosing and designing your own reviews, but also in identifying and assessing published literature reviews that may help advance your work.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Music moves us physically and emotionally. Even when we don't move, brain areas related to movement are active when we hear music. Yet traditionally, music has by and large been studied from written scores, which can tell us many things. Scores do not, however, tell us how that music actually sounds or makes us feel. Moreover, it lacks the second most important aspect of music: movement. In recent years, developing technologies and blurring borders between scientific fields have paved the way for studying music from the perspective of human movement. Embodied Music Cognition is an exciting young field in musicology, which has as its core premise that movement in all its facets provides a unique window into musical and human behaviour. This course introduces students to many facets of the field, including the origins and purpose(s) of music, neuroscience, digital audio and emotions, and offers 4 weeks of intensive hands-on experience with students running, analysing and writing up their own music research project.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

column1: The research thesis (30 EC) is the final examination of the program and an integrative assessment demonstrating that you have achieved the learning goals for the program: having the knowledge and the skills needed to set up and carry out scientific research projects in one area of business and management, with the use of data science techniques. It showcases your ability to identify relevant problems and address them using cutting-edge methods to make a substantive contribution to the field. To this end, you will write an individual research project, under the guidance of your assigned supervisor(s). The research project (thesis) should be potentially publishable in an internationally per-reviewed journal in your field. It should follow academic standards in terms of editing, ethical data handling, and methodological rigor.

The thesis comes with a predefense. The predefense should be organized when about 80% of the research is done. The predefense should result in a to-do list for the student towards completing the thesis.
Note: You are encouraged to be pro-active in selecting a research topic for the thesis and in soliciting potential supervisors towards the end of the first year and beginning of the second year.

column1: Inleiding in de Taalfilosofie, waarin de vraag naar wat betekenis is, centraal zal staan. Diverse betekenistheorieën zullen de revue passeren (Locke, Frege-Russell, Grice-Searle, Putnam, Quine, Davidson, Wittgenstein). Begrippen zoals referentie, taalhandeling, waarheid, regel-volgen en hun relatie met betekenis zullen we ons eigen maken. Thesen als relativisme, onder-bepaling van referentie en onvertaalbaarheid zullen we tegen het licht houden.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The ability to hire talented people is probably one of the most important drivers of business success. However, in business schools there is zero to none academic training in “hiring people”. This is striking because “hiring” makes up for a large part of the day-to-day agenda of business leaders and the academic evidence on what is good practice has multiple gaps with what happens in everyday professional life. For instance, many organizations still base selection decisions on invalid and unreliable selection methods, resulting in low-quality hiring decisions.

This course will provide insights in the fundamentals of the talent acquisition process, how to effectively acquire for- and match talent to business needs, and modern-day talent acquisition/ /selection methods. The course engages students through a combination of lectures, practical case studies, exercises and discussions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the fundamentals of talent acquisition, recruitment and selection methods
• Explain the interfaces between talent acquisition and other elements of the organization
• Apply the theoretical knowledge to a business case
• Be able to critically evaluate business cases

column1: In groups of 4-5 students, you write a scientific article that deals with the theme allocated to you. The themes will be determined at the start of the course. Topic descriptions and the tools will be uploaded before the first lecture. The article should be policy oriented backed by a clear economic analysis.

In writing your article, you should keep in mind your readership. The article is meant to be a science-based contribution to an actual policy debate, that could be useful for policy makers at the Ministry of Finance, but firmly rooted in academic literature and methodology.

Given the theme that is allocated to your group, you will have some freedom in performing the research and writing the article. For instance, you should develop your own research question. Moreover, we provide an instrument for analysis, which you should use for the paper. How you use it, is up to you. There are also one or more complementary articles that explain more carefully how the analytical tool has been used in previous research.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The aim of this course is to foster the ability of students to conduct economic research on a policy relevant topic.
• Students can write a well structured research proposal.
• Students can answer a policy relevant question with methods used by applied economists.
• Students can write a short well structured research paper.
• Students can present their work to policymakers and fellow students.
• Students train their ability to conduct an applied policy analysis themselves.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Omwille van de coronamaatregelen zullen er dit jaar minder fysieke begeleidingsmomenten zijn, en wordt het bezoek aan het ministerie van financiën waarschijnlijk geannuleerd. We beperken ons dit jaar tot econometrische opdrachten.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course ‘Taxation’ you will learn the fundamentals of business taxation including the effects of taxation on financial planning and business decisions. This course provides you with an overview of which taxes exist, to which natural or legal persons they apply, how taxation affects business decisions, and with the fundamentals of domestic and international business taxation.

The course is about concepts of taxation supported by country specific details that are present in tax systems of most industrialized countries around the world. We will take the view of an entrepreneur and apply the concepts of taxation to cases to take tax-optimal decisions. While we often use a Dutch setting, the course is not designed to introduce you to the details of Dutch tax law. We learn about different types of taxes and which are relevant for businesses. We include taxes into investment and financing decisions, learn how partnerships and corporations are taxed, and discuss whether taxation is about minimizing taxes only.

Finally, you get to know the structure of international tax law, double tax treaties, and multilateral agreements. The course combines financial accounting, tax accounting, and investment principles to answer the question: How do I take tax-optimal business decisions? This implies that you anchor in what you know from previous classes in financial accounting and combine it with new content of the taxation class.

The fundamentals of domestic and international taxation form basic knowledge of auditors, tax advisors, and practitioners in the accounting or tax departments of multinationals. Thus, the course is of interest to those thinking about careers in accounting, consulting, and corporate finance.

You must attend at least 6 lectures or workshops. I will check attendance in each session. If you attend fewer than 6 lectures or workshops, your case grade will be reduced by 0.3 grade points per not attended lecture.
There is a guest lecture on April 22. It is mandatory to attend the guest lecture on campus.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Solve tasks that include taxes in financial planning
• Analyze the impact of taxation on organizational form choices
• Evaluate when business profits and when shareholder level profits are taxed
• Evaluate double tax agreements and multilateral agreements in the area of international taxation
• Create recommendations for business decisions including taxes and present them in a report

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112350,2023,Taxation of Multinationals,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. DS Schindler'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In international taxation, the most prominent and hotly debated issue is how to tax multinational companies. In other words, the debate is about how to handle profit-shifting activities by multinationals, or international corporate tax avoidance in more general. Anecdotic evidence shows that large multinational companies such as Google and Apple, but also IKEA manage to avoid almost all tax payments. Even state-owned companies like the Norwegian Equinor (formerly Statoil) use international tax shelters to reduce their global tax payments.

The issue became a major challenge to public policy. Being concerned about losses in tax revenue and an imbalance in the distribution of the tax burden on individuals and firms, the G20 countries and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) started the still ongoing “Base Erosion and Profit Shifting” (BEPS) project in 2012 that in recent years came up with various proposals to regulate firms’ activities and their scope to shift profits. In its 2013-report, the OECD states that “at stake is the integrity of the corporate income tax”.

On the other hand, corporate income taxes are (one of) the biggest cost blocks in corporations, and it appears natural that firms try to reduce costs and respond to tax incentives. Indeed, (some) profit shifting can reduce the distortions created by taxing mobile capital investment and help to implement a beneficial tax differentiation between mobile and immobile tax bases.

Consequently, both profit shifting and its regulation via anti-avoidance rules come with benefits and costs. To be in a position to evaluate the implications of profit shifting, the need and design of regulation, the impact of tax havens, but also to understand the decision making in multinationals and their structure, it is first necessary to have a good understanding of

column2: • how international tax regulation looks like, and
• how multinationals minimize their global tax payments.

column1: Following up on these issues, the course has three parts, beyond setting the stage in chapters 1 and 2. Part 1 focuses on transfer pricing of intra-firm trade as a tax-avoidance channel (chapter 3). Part 2 examines international debt shifting in a tax-efficient capital structure as a tool to save taxes (chapters 4 to 6). Finally, Part 3 discusses the institutional design and the effects of the most important anti-avoidance regulation (thin capitalization rule, controlled-foreign-company rules) in chapter 7 and recent policy proposals on formula apportionment and global minimum taxation in chapter 8.
The structure of the course roughly is as follows:
2. The International Tax System: A Basic Overview
3. Transfer Pricing and International Profit Shifting
4. Capital Structure and Taxation in a Domestic Firm
7. Anti-avoidance Regulation: Thin Capitalization Rules, CFC rules (and CCCTB)
8. Formula Apportionment and Recent Tax Reform Proposals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Acquired an advanced understanding of the theory behind how international taxation affects firm behavior.
• Can explain the main regulatory framework and institutional setting to limit international tax avoidance.
• Can formally analyze and derive how international taxation and its institutional framework affect tax-efficient (financing) structures and investment in multinational firms.
• Can evaluate the welfare impact of tax havens and the design of regulation.
• Are able to assess empirical evidence on both multinationals’ tax avoidance and its regulation.
• Can design independent empirical studies on profit shifting.
• Are able to critically assess the implications of future changes in regulation and the institutional setting.
• Can apply their acquired knowledge on international tax avoidance and firms’ behavior in a theoretical, abstract setting that still allows for evaluating practical cases.
• Can utilize their advanced expertise on international income shifting by transfer prices and debt in real-world situations.
• Be able to critically evaluate pro and cons of profit shifting and its regulation.
• Be in a position to communicate with specialists in both academia and practice about complex issues in international tax avoidance and the BEPS debate.

column1: <body>Contemporary culture is out of phase with technical progression, either considering it as a threat or as neutral matter to be exploited by humanity. According to the philosopher of technology Gilbert Simondon, both positions are inadequate. Instead, technology must be understood in its technicity, which is fully relational and involves a reconsideration of classical conceptual dualisms such as form and matter, design and production, work and life, all of which obscure the mode of existence of technical objects. In this intensive three-week workshop students will examine how the form and the function of technical objects have the capacity to transform both humans and environment. The aim is to extract knowledge from the readings and orient them into speculative research statements that will produce a series of material and technological experimentations as a final output. The students work in transdisciplinarily composed groups of max. 5 and are asked to produce a physical model that serves as the materialisation of their speculative research statement. In addition, they should prepare supplementary material to the model, such as drawings or short texts. The students are asked to present their models and other material in the end of the workshop in 20 min. presentations followed by (peer-)feedback. The products will be exhibited online.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of the three modules, the students will have:

o Acquired the academic skills for thinking, reading, presenting, and collaborating in an inclusive and transdisciplinary manner, in particular a sensibility for problems at the interface of architecture and philosophy;
o Acquired a conceptual toolbox for thinking in terms of relations and speculative-interactive design;

o Learned to apply contemporary ideas and debates in a dynamic urban setting in engaged, responsible, and non-reactive ways; Acquired or developed basic (technical) design skills while contributing to ecological literacy.

column1: In this practical, the student becomes familiar with, and learns to use different neuroscientific research techniques that can be used in forensic neuroscience, such as electroencephalography (EEG), (functional) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and transcranial Current Stimulation (tCS). It is important that the student learns that, especially in this target group of forensic patients, neuroscientific research offers starting points for practice (including violence risk assessment and management), and is therefore an evidence-based approach.
In addition, the students will learn to use all this information on neuroscientific research techniques to write a report to the court as expert witness.</body>
