column1: During this course, the student learns to:

column2: • Make an informed choice for different neuropsychological or neuroscientific methods to investigate suspects and perpetrators.
• Explain in the role of expert witness on the basis of neuroscientific information why a particular punishment or measure is or is not appropriate for a particular suspect.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115886,2023,Technology and Social Change,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. C Brunner'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Philosophically, technology is a concept that is derived from the practice of making or doing – in ancient Greek tékhnē. Mundane associations of technology, however, relate to the modern paradigm of mechanics, and, more recently, digital computing. In its very foundation, technology relates to practice, back then mostly human practice. It bears a sense of artifice, of activity, of something not quite given as such but something fabricated. It comes as no surprise that Western philosophy began to ask how that what was classically deemed a human or natural activity (there is tékhnē in nature too) got out of hand and became self-reliant. A possibly familiar exposure of that anxiety comes to the fore in romantic literature of the early to mid-18th century, where machines become monsters (E.T.A. Hoffmann’s Sandman) and humans are turned into monstruous machines (Mary Shelly’s Frankenstein). The romantic lineage predates the development of the proper field of the philosophy of technology. The latter continues some of the key themes of Romanticism: the rise of the self-reliant machine and the alienation of the human. Even in contemporary debates around AI and automation the undertone of technology’s danger, especially for the human species, is omnipresent. Technology can and should never be separated from either nature or society. Technology and the philosophy of technology allow us to rethink the relation between nature and culture, finally resolving their opposition.

This course will provide a glimpse at the Western tradition of the philosophy of technology, while also aiming to disrupt and deviate some of the popular images of technology in society. Therefore, technology will be considered as part of social practices, where the social, however, exceeds conventional understandings of society as interrelated human beings. The emphasis of this course lies in technology AND social change – giving no priority to either while underlining their co-emergence. Philosophically, we might term such an approach pragmatist, that is, based on processes and practices, not eternal truths.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of the course, students should
a) have acquired basic knowledge of the concepts and debates in the philosophy of technology.

b) be able to describe and analyze technological developments with regard to their relation to social changes; compare and contrast the different kinds of scientific reasoning relevant to the philosophy of technology and related scientific studies of technology; reflect critically on the assumptions, strengths and limitations of the different perspectives and concepts of technology; apply this knowledge to analyze how recent technology and society mutually shape each other.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115112,2023,Technology, Media and Identity",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. JH Pridmore'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The integration of new forms of technology and media into everyday life have begun to alter our sense of who we are and what we are about as human beings. Our sense of self – our identity – has shifted as ubiquitous technology and predictive algorithms become part of our social experiences. This is clearly evident in forms of social media, news and entertainment, but digitalisation has also changed the way we work, the way we shop, the way we date and the way we relate to our families. This course begins to explore these themes, starting with a clearer understanding of how social interaction and relationships produce and affect identity and how technology has become a mediating factor in our identity ‘constructions’. This is an incremental change from previous notions of self that were intimately attached to place, name and status or position. By focusing on media and technology, the course is intended to develop students’ critical self-reflective awareness of identity in the contemporary era and how media and technology affect the current and future shaping of self. The course draws on contemporary theories of identity, but also takes a practical approach by examining several domains in which identity is shaped. These domains take into consideration how technology and media are integrated into family and intimate relationships, workplaces, marketing, politics, entertainment, and news, giving grounding for a deeper understanding and awareness of identity in these contexts.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The nature of identity theory as a field of social scientific study.
• The basic theories, concepts, and notions of identity and the ‘self’.
• The effects and influences of technology and media on identity.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Analyse how media and technology intersect with constructions of identity.
• Appraise differing technologies and their influence in communication contexts and domains that are part of people’s personal and professional lives.
• Evaluate and reflect on the ways in which ubiquitous technology and predictive technologies will evolve in the future and the implications for people’s future sense of self.
• Present and communicate their findings and viewpoints in writing, oral presentation, and discussion.
• Reflect on how media and technology is influencing their personal life.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110628,2023,Technology, Policy and Society",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. A Albareda Sanz', 'dr. RFI Moody']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Today’s society is characterized by many as an information society. The industrial society, which was typical for the 19th and the first half of the 20th century, has transformed because of economic and cultural changes into a society in which information and information dissemination are central. The course technology democracy and society focusses on the role of modern ICT  within today’s society and in today’s democracy. The course will elaborate on which societal transformations are set in motion by the use of modern ICT and which consequences these societal transformations can have for the way in which ICT is used and perceived within society. Additionally topics such as chain information between organizations, interplay between technology and democracy and ethical issues will be discussed. In this course the main topics within the public sector related to technology will be addressed, among others, how big and open data influences the policy process, how computerized predictions can impact the way actors make decisions within matters in the public domain such as water management, climate change or safety and security and how this changes the dynamics of power within policy making, also we will address how the role of policy makers and those involved in the public sector changes into an information broker. Subsequently these changes have an effect on society and this effect will also be elaborated on.

De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding / For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After having followed the course, students are able to

column2: • Name which patterns and changes form the basis of today's information society
• Explain how dynamics within the policy process within the public sector change as a result of technology and the emergence of an information society and how this reflects on society
• Explain how public organizations and those employed there change as a result of technological change
• Explain how technology is applied in organizations and cooperation between organizations
• Name and reflect on ethical dilemmas regarding the use of technology

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114807,2023,Television Audiences,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. JC van Sterkenburg'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Central in this course are research on television audiences and on audience reception. While many studies focus on the content of media, audience receptions of that content have been under-researched. Consequently, conclusions about media impact often remain rather speculative. In this course, we will explore how television audiences interpret and receive popular television genres and ‘texts’. We will pay attention, amongst other things, to the role played by social dimensions like race, ethnicity, gender, (dis)ability, social class, and religion in audience receptions. Television can be considered a powerful source for giving meaning to these social dimensions, while different viewers can negotiate and interpret these meanings in multiple ways.  Various forms of qualitative data-collection and data–analysis (e.g. individual interviews, focus groups, construction of topic list) will be discussed in order to prepare students to conduct independent research into television audiences. The assignments give students room to focus on TV genres/formats they are interested in. The various steps in the actual research process will be discussed and related to specific assignments in the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The interaction between media representations and audience receptions;
• Audience reception research, with a specific focus on popular television genres and social dimensions such as gender, race, ethnicity, religion;
• The different components of qualitative audience-related research and how these components relate to each other.
• Conduct qualitative audience research into TV audiences both individually and in teams.
• Reflect critically on methodological and theoretical articles in the field;

column1: Apply practical skills required for qualitative audience research, e.g. drafting a topic list, interviewing, qualitative data-analysis, presenting findings.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115255,2023,Television Industries in the Age of Streaming,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. ML Wayne'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This is an exciting and transformative moment for television industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, video on-demand services that provide directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. The growth of Disney+’s subscriber base to more than 100 million users in less than eighteen months, for example, demonstrates traditional players’ commitment to streaming distribution. Similarly, the global expansion of streaming platforms like Netflix are simultaneously reflections and drivers of change within the traditional television industries. To address these issues, this course uses a variety of interdisciplinary paradigms to understand television industries in the age of streaming.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Theoretical approaches and key concepts related to the analysis of television industries.
• Perspectives on television at the level of industry, audience, and text.
• Analyze and explain television industries in a variety of contemporary contexts.
• Reflect critically on the mainstream and academic discourses surrounding television industries.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114361,2023,Terrorism, extremism and control",Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,"['AEM Driessen', 'AI Marzouk', 'dr.mr. F Geelhoed', 'JM de Dood, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides insight into the phenomena of terrorism, extremism, and their control. This implies that, on the one hand, the phenomena and their manifestations are discussed in their diversity. This part concerns topics such as the definition, history and characteristics, the crime-terror nexus, radicalization processes, explanations for terrorism/extremism and radicalization, the attraction of extremist groups, resilience against radicalization and disengagement. On the other hand, this course focuses on the policies and legal approach to terrorism and their relationship to human rights.
Recurring themes in reflecting on these issues are the dilemmas involved in the control of terrorism, extremism and radicalization and their possible unintended consequences.
Interactive lectures/seminars in which students are expected to actively process the subject matter in collaboration with each other and in interaction with the (guest) lecturer(s).
To participate in the lectures/seminars each week a preparation form needs to be made and uploaded.
<body>After successfully completing this course you will be able to:

column2: • Differentiate between various forms, qualifications and explanations for terrorism, extremism and radicalization;
• Select relevant academic literature about a concrete case of extremism or terrorism;
• Appraise knowledge about extremism, terrorism, radicalization in relation to concrete manifestations and perpetrators;
• Argue what the diverse relations between the state and terrorism and crime and terrorism are in concrete cases;
• Argue how knowledge about the phenomena relates to their control and the possible unintended consequences of control;
• Reflect critically on current dilemmas, social justice and the safeguarding of human rights in counterterrorism practice;
• Formulate recommendations for control on the basis of your findings.

column1: Dit practicum bouwt voort op de diverse practica waarin studenten kennis en ervaring hebben opgedaan van verschillende aspecten van het meer klinische werk als pedagoog. In dit practicum leer je om diagnostiek uit te voeren en daarbij oog te hebben op verschillende factoren die van invloed kunnen zijn op de ontwikkeling van een kind.

De studenten oefenen met het afnemen van diagnostische instrumenten bij een kind in de basisschoolleeftijd (bij voorkeur zonder ontwikkelingsproblemen). Daarnaast worden de gedragsontwikkeling en de (opvoed)omgeving in kaart gebracht. Als eindopdracht schrijft de student een klinisch onderzoeksverslag met ouders als doelgroep, zodat ze oefenen met het vertalen van onderzoeksresultaten naar leken. Daarnaast wordt er in de bijeenkomsten geoefend met het voeren van gesprekken met ouders over de onderzoeksresultaten. De testafname en/of het oudergesprek wordt geëvalueerd in een zelfreflectieverslag.

In het practicum wordt er duidelijk een connectie gemaakt met de klinische praktijk. De kennis en vaardigheden die in dit practicum worden opgedaan zijn een goede voorbereiding op de praktijkstage in de bachelor of master

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • een uitgebreid ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek af te nemen bij een kind (eindtermen 5 en 10);
• de opvoedingsomgeving van het kind te observeren en te coderen met behulp van gestandaardiseerde, gevalideerde instrumenten (eindtermen 5 en 10);
• bevindingen uit het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek op een praktijkgerichte manier te beschrijven;
• bevindingen uit het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek terug te koppelen aan een ouder;
• peerfeedback te geven en ontvangen en op basis hiervan eigen werk kritisch te beschouwen en te verbeteren (eindtermen 18 en 19);
• en zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):
• een samenhangende en heldere tekst te schrijven (eindterm 15);
• een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen (eindtermen 15 en 16);
• een testrapport met de geëigende structuurindeling te schrijven (eindtermen 15 en 16).

column1: In an age where customer opinion and feedback can have an immediate, major effect upon the success of a business or organization, marketers must have the ability to analyze unstructured data in everything from social media and internet reviews to customer surveys or phone logs. This course provides students with tools that enable them to effectively implement and use text analytics in a marketing context. In the course the complete analysis process, from data input, summarizing and visualizing and rigorous statistical analysis, will be covered.

The main content is provided via short video lectures. An application with Q&A will be discussed in class. In addition, students will make a group assignment to gain hands on experience with the techniques from the course.

column1: <body>Each week, you will perform an R assignment based on an online video tutorial. The video tutorials will be accessible via Canvas. You will perform the assignments at home on your personal computer (pc or mac). The first tutorial will introduce you to the basic functionalities of RStudio. Each of the three subsequent video tutorials will guide you through a specific aspect of the Twitter research flow. In the second tutorial you will learn how to independently collect a large dataset of Twitter messages (i.e., tweets and complementary information). The third tutorial will show you how to preprocess the data and how to perform a sentiment classification (i.e. how to classify Twitter messages into ‘positive’ and ‘negative’ categories). The final tutorial will guide you to analyze your results and produce descriptive and inferential statistics and figures.</body>

column1: <body>The purpose of this practicum is twofold: you will learn how to use R and you will independently perform a comprehensive research procedure involving the investigation of (text-based) Twitter data.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115020,2023,The Art of Choosing: Making choices that maximize happiness,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. J Boegershausen'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Choices ranging from the mundane to the profound are essential to our daily life. Given the proliferation of digital technologies and consumption in all spheres of life, we make more choices than ever before. Just consider how many choices you already made today before you started reading this course manual. At a more fundamental level, being able to decide for ourselves can provide a sense of control and autonomy that is essential to well-being and human flourishing. Yet how to make choices that bring us happiness, provide purpose, and allow us to enhance our quality of life and well-being often remains elusive.

Together we will deconstruct choice and why it matters so much. The minor explores whether there ever can be too much choice and the myriad influences that context has on our decisions and choices. At the end of the course, you will be able to leverage these insights to make better choices for the good of yourself and others.

Understanding and overcoming our own biases and shortcomings in choice may not only increase happiness but also can facilitate being a force for positive change. At a more personal level, the Art of Choosing is designed to help every single course participant reflect on what “the good life,” i.e., a life well-lived, means to you. During the course, we will examine different perspectives ranging from the good life as happy, meaningful, and to the psychologically rich life. In the words of Aristotle, “knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.” This minor will equip you with frameworks and tools to craft and curate compelling customer experiences that facilitate better choices for consumers and firms alike.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Understand how choices influence different forms of happiness
Identify and analyze relevant situational influences that might shape choice
Engage in critical self-reflection about your own decisions
Learn how we can make better choices for ourselves and others
Evaluate different approaches to curate choice sets and assortments that create value for consumers and firms
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113127,2023,The Avant-Garde: Experimental Art, Photography and Film",Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Avant-Garde is the French military term for front-guard and is generally used to describe the most adventurous manifestations of modern art, photography and film. Art – in the broadest sense of the word - that forges ahead, breaks down barriers and challenges the status quo, but at the same time, art that is difficult, sometimes incomprehensible and elitist. Through a combination of the humanities and sociological perspectives, we will trace the roots of the Avant-Garde, examine the challenges that avant-garde artists faced and discuss whether avant-garde art is still possible today.

The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts (i.e. fine arts, photography, film) and society from – roughly - 1850 to the present. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context; research appropriate literature; and create self-formulated questions.

All this will lead up to a symposium that we will organise at the end of the course, during which students will present and discuss short papers about the several themes that we discussed during our lectures and museum visits.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts and society for approximately the last 150 years. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context; research appropriate literature; and create self-formulated questions.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111075,2023,The Brain,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. MI Sahan'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The brain: maybe the most important organ of our body. Without the brain we would not be aware of anything around us. The world would not exist for us. It’s not our eyes that make us see, it’s not our ears that make us hear. It is only in our brain were we become aware of what we see and what we hear. In this course you will learn about this exciting organ, the brain, with its neural circuits giving rise to psychological functions like cognition and emotion.

Everything that happens in the brain is the result of interactions between brain cells, the neurons. Neurons communicate with each other through chemical substances. In this block you will learn how this communication takes place and what happens when this communication goes wrong in clinical disorders like depression and schizophrenia. You will also learn how the brain develops, how neural circuits arise and how these are subject to modifications as a result of experience.

Brain research is constantly giving us new ideas about how the brain works and what happens when things seem to go wrong in the brain. There are still many things that we (or better ‘science’) do not exactly know about the brain. This makes it a very exciting topic to study. If everything would be known already, it would be less fun. Actually, some say that we might never be able to understand the brain completely. As L. Watson, a well-known scientist, said:
”If the brain were so simple we could understand it, we would be so simple we couldn't.”

Indeed, brain is a comprehensive subject.  You will learn a lot of new names and terms and this might be a little confusing in the beginning. When you feel like this, just think of the following quote from another scientist, W. Rogers:
“You know you've got to exercise your brain just like your muscles"".</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of this course, you will have a deeper understanding of

column2: •          the cellular basis of brain functioning and neural circuits (including the role and working of neurotransmitters and receptors, and the cascade that the binding of a neurotransmitter to a receptor sets off).
•          how neural circuits arise in the development of the brain.
•          how modifications of neural circuits take place as a result of experience and learning
•         the biological basis of brain dysfunctions (e.g. psychiatric disorders) and the working of psychotropic drugs
•         the process of recovery after brain damage, involving neuroplasticity

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The media sector is an important economic industry that is increasingly expanding into other sectors such as healthcare or connected vehicles. During this course we focus  on the  media  firm as  our unit of analysis  and we will use the  business  model canvas  as  our main   analytical model.

During the classes we will discuss how media firms design value  propositions, engage with customers, produce content and services (value chains), manage their organizations and generate revenues. We will address the impact of new (digital) media technologies on the business models of media firms. Furthermore, we will also look at specific business related issues that media firms face in specific sectors, such as TV, gaming and digital video. We will also address how government policy impacts business models of media firms, for instance around copyrights, privacy and competition law.

An important part of this course consists of guest lectures by people that work in media companies. These guest lecturers will familiarize students with real life experiences around the topics that will be discussed.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Theoretical approaches, key concepts and current developments in the field of media business and media management;
• The operations of contemporary media organizations from a management and business perspective;
• Read, critique, and apply relevant theoretical concepts to specific business related issues faced by media firms
• Analyze and critically reflect upon the use of business models by media firms

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Climate Crisis: Ecology, Economy & Politics in the Anthropocene
There is consensus among scientists in fields that are contributing to the study of climate change
that mankind has a negative impact on our climate and that we are rapidly running out of time to
avert a catastrophically changed climate. Still we mankind, as a whole - do not seem to be in a
hurry to change the ways in which we have organised our everyday lives, our economies and our
societies. Why? And what is to be done?
In this course we discuss the ways in which we shape the climate and the climate has shaped, and
will continue to shape, us from the very distant past to the not so distant future. By combining
perspectives from philosophical anthropology, psychology, political economy and (geo)politics
students get a thorough introduction into the problematic of climate change. Throughout the
course we pay particular attention to the concept of the Anthropocene as well as its uses and
abuses in popular discourse and academic disciplines as varied as climate sciences, geology, social

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have a basic understanding of the causes and consequences of Climate Change;
• Have a basic understanding of the debate about the (use and abuse of the term) Anthropocene;
• Have a basic understanding of economic solutions to climate change;
• Have a basic understanding of the politics of climate change;
• Have a basic understanding of the pros and cons of technological fixes;
• Have a basic understanding of the SF mode in both its literary and theoretical sense;
• Have an advanced understanding of the work of key thinkers on Climate Change such as Latour and Haraway, Moore and Giddens and Morton and Jonas.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114930,2023,The Cultural Economic Perspective,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. CW Handke'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main objective of this course is to familiarize students with key concepts and major perspectives – developments, trends, and problems – in the economics of art and culture. The course will present the cultural economic perspective as developed by David Throsby, Michael Hutter, Bruno Frey and Arjo Klamer. The central question is how artists and cultural organizations realize the social and cultural values of their artistic work. We will consider the relevance for cultural policies in the Dutch and European context.

During the lectures these concepts will be discussed mainly from a theoretical perspective, but the workgroups will focus on applying them to concrete economic phenomena that are familiar to students from their everyday life or from the world of arts and culture.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The goal of this course is to familiarize students with what has come to be called the cultural economic perspective. After this course students should be able to identify the differences between this perspective and the standard economic perspective, and they are expected to be able to analyze various phenomena using the cultural economic perspective.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114821,2023,The Future of the Creative Labour Market,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. YGD Wijngaarden'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Work in the creative industries often means following your passion and enjoying the freedom to structure your life according to your preferences. Yet, work in the creative industries is also precarious, unstable, and not equally available for everyone. Despite good intentions and policies, there is a profound and persistent problem of inequality and low pay in the creative industries.

Being just a couple of months away from entering the labour market as a Media and Creative Industries/Media, Culture and Society graduate, we discuss what the creative industries entail, and what makes these industries stand out from the perspective of labor and labor market organization. Think about the project-based organization of work, the prevalence of freelance work, and the importance of networking and reputation.

Yet, in this course, we also move beyond describing the status quo. We will identify new developments that will affect or are already affecting the organization of the creative industries. Think about new ways of getting your work funded (crowdfunding), technological developments (Web3, AI), or new initiatives to make the creative industries more diverse.

This course is characterized by a strong orientation towards the creative labor market. We will invite creative workers to talk about their innovative practices in guest lectures. Students are encouraged to connect to firms and organizations and are asked to reflect on their position as a (soon to be) creative professional. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course, students will have knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Apply relevant theoretical insights in the analysis of creative labour;
• Critically assess various texts (academic texts, industry reports, policy documents) addressing creative labour;
• Set up an academic argument on creative labour, verbally, visually, and in writing.
• Reflect on and make informed choices regarding their future careers.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115900,2023,The High Enlightenment,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. L van Bunge'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

By 1750s the French Enlightenment in particular takes off its gloves. Diderot and D’Holbach start propagating a ‘Spinozist’ materialism, which raises the issue of the origins of the Radical Enlightenment. Simultaneously Rousseau singlehandedly revolutionizes French political thought. Meanwhile, the German Enlightenment (Thomasius, Wolff, Lessing) gets under way and the eighteenth-century culture of sensibility spreads throughout Europe. Following the French Revolution, Burke and De Maistre launch their Counter-Enlightenment, the echoes of which can still be traced in twentieth-century critical accounts of the Enlightenment such as Adorno and Horkheimer’s Dialectics of Enlightenment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

Having completed this course, students will be familiar with some of the main ideas put forward by D’Holbach and the so-called ‘radical Enlightenment’. They will understand the main characteristics of Rousseau’s thought. They will be able to distinguish some of the key differences between the French and the German Enlightenment. They will know some of the most important critical assessments of the Enlightenment, put forward during the late eighteenth and the twentieth centuries.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114708,2023,The International System,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. Y van Hoef', 'KM Senneville, MSc', 'prof.dr. M Onderco', 'prof.dr. W Hout']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This module provides an introduction to the development of the international political system from 1500 to the present. The focus is on the highest, systemic level: the practice of international politics, its main actors, the rules, assumptions, understandings, and norms that underpinned said practice, and how all of these changed over time. Particular attention will be paid to key moments in international history, such as peace conferences, global encounters, major wars, and international institution-building, from the encounters of separate civilisations in the 1500s to today’s global governance.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1.       Students will be able to analyse the evolution of the international system since 1500;
2.       Students will be able to evaluate theoretical perspectives on the role of ideas versus power in shaping international order since 1500;
3.       Students will be able to originate a response paper critically assessing current claims about the future of the international system in the twenty-first century.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115849,2023,The Invention of Pollution: A Playful Investigation,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. YH Hendlin'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is part of the 'Environment, Life and Technology' cluster (cluster 2).

Is pollution just matter out of place? Or is there also thought pollution? Are advertisements matter out of place for some – jarring intrusions into our everyday lives – while being precisely placed by marketers? So, is marketing the discipline of creating pollution? Has psychology been hijacked to make people more neurotic? Has philosophy been spun to create more sophistry? Is there any thing, form, or substance that is incorruptible? If we wish for things to be uncorrupted, why are we in search for it externally? Why are we looking to others for solutions that require changing human character and society?

No other creature in existence produces artifacts that cannot usefully be broken down by other biological organisms. Nor do they concentrate toxins in given areas, or sequester them, festering away, creating dysbiosis. Biological input and output for organisms, then becomes an ecological cycle, where the detritus/effluent/scraps/excrement of one species becomes the food for another in an everflowing chain of composting.

But not industrial culture. While there have been those who bit off the hand that fed them, like the Rapa Nui of Easter Island, such cultures were constrained, geographically, energetically, and ecologically. But industrial culture, with its goals of sustaining unsustainable ways of concentrating power, and then finding ways of fighting back and circumventing ecological, social, psychological, and physiological limits, aims to establish and maintain a status quo of control, no matter the fallout. The collateral damage of this way of separating the self from the environment, undermines the fertility of that which enables the opportunities that begat that/those being(s).

Questions discussed include: When did pollution first begin? What form did it take? Why did it come to pass? What is the link between pollution and instrumentalism? How did pollution become globalized? How was pollution mobilized for colonization? What is pollution’s ‘endgame’? Would you be willing to live without pollution if we all did? Does giving up pollution mean giving up all technology, or might there be some other way to enjoy the fruits of technology without polluting?
Students must attend all seminars except in emergencies communicated before the missed course session in question. Students missing more than 2 seminar sessions are dropped from the class.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Learn about the history of pollution from several different philosophical perspectives.
• Examine philosophical anthropology applied to a specific case study.
• Analyze different arguments for what constitutes pollution, why it is (un)necessary, and what it reflects.
• Compare competing narratives of pollution and its purposes (the performativity of pollution.

• Synthesize perspectives to form your own original argument, and defend it with argumentation and logic against counterarguments (or modify your original claim in light of convincing counterarguments).

column1: Course participants will learn about the principles and rules governing the European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). Here the focus lies on the general characteristics of EMU and its shortcomings (asymmetric integration), the economic and legal objectives and principles underlying economic policy coordination, the different Union and extra-Union instruments that define the preventive and corrective arms of the Stability and Growth Pact and the Macroeconomic Imbalance Procedure (namely ‘six-pack’ legislation, ‘two-pack’ legislation, and the Fiscal Compact), the conditions for granting financial assistance to Member States (notably, Article 122 TFEU, Article 125 TFEU & the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism), the constitutional implications of the financial assistance programmes, as well as the institutional position and tasks of the European System of Central Banks and the European Central Bank (ECB) before, during, and in the aftermath of the European sovereign debt crisis. Moreover, some parallels will be drawn to the COVID-19 crisis, and we will also look at the impact of the Member States’ and EU responses to this latest crisis on the future development of EMU.

Course participants will moreover understand the principles and rules governing the European System of Financial Supervision and the European Banking Union. In providing participants with a useful overview, the focus lies on the overall supervisory architecture (namely the role of the three European Supervisory Authorities and the ECB’s Supervisory Board), an overview of the main features of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (Regulations 1024/2013 and 1022/2013), as well as the main features of the Single Resolution Mechanism and the Single Resolution Fund (Regulation 806/2014, the Intergovernmental Agreement on the transfer and mutualisation of contributions to the Single Resolution Fund, and the reform of the European Stability Mechanism which would provide the backstop to the fund). It is further envisaged to include guest lectures on relevant current developments, such as the greening of monetary policy and of the financial markets in response to the climate crisis.

Throughout the course particular attention will be paid to (1) explaining the (political) economic rationale for the institutional arrangements and (2) highlighting the close link between economic and monetary integration, but also between EMU and the regulation and supervision of financial markets in the EU, which stresses the need for an integrated approach to the study of these fields of law.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>With their participation in this course, students will learn more about the regulation of economic and monetary integration in the European Union (EU), as well as the supervision of financial markets in the EU internal market. The financial and public debt crisis threw into sharp relief the importance of these policy areas and led to an overhaul of the relevant legal and institutional framework. The Eurozone and its future are at the forefront of legal, economic, and political debates. More recently, the COVID-19 crisis gave rise to new challenges for the Economic and Monetary Union, while at the same time also exposing some old problems that have not been fully resolved.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: History has seen many types of global orders, from multiple co-existing isolated systems to global unipolar hegemony. This course explores the evolution of the origins of global order from ca. 1500 to the Vienna Settlement of 1815.

On the one hand it seeks to explain how and why certain powers emerged to dominance to define the global order, what strategies and mechanisms they developed that allowed them to order global relations, and how these powers justified their dominance of the global order. On the other hand, this course examines the plethora of challenges to global order, from revisionist powers seeking to develop alternative orders to normative challenges from within the global order.

Through viewing the evolution of global order from a global history perspective, this course aims to challenge some of the established Eurocentric perspectives on the origins and early history of global order.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Drawing on History and International Relations Theory, students can conceptualise global order and related concepts;
• Students can analyse how order was constructed, deconstructed and reconstructed across the globe, 1500-1815;
• Students can discern various scholarly views on the rise and decline of international primacy and how this affects the global order.
• Through learning journal assignments, students can navigate, criticise, and defend scholarly opinions to develop their own substantiated views on key episodes of the history of global order.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116409,2023,The Philosophy and Economics of Climate Change,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. CB Binder', 'dr. HCK Heilmann']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Climate change is one of the defining challenges of our current times. It raises many questions at the intersection of philosophy and economics, such as: Should fundamental assumptions about economic growth, welfare, and discounting that are typically made in economic theory and modeling be changed or given up? Are climate policy models, such as integrated assessment models (IAMs) truly up to the job? Are carbon pricing and taxing the right economic tools to tackle climate change? Should our assessment in welfare economics be changed and adapted to account for matters of climate justice and if so, how? Do we need to rethink our current socio-economic system in times of sustainable transitions more radically? Does economics as a profession need to change, or are any calls for radical change overblown?

In this course we discuss cutting-edge research pertaining to these questions at the core of climate change debates in the field of philosophy of economics. More specifically, students are introduced in a first step to the core methodological debates on economic modelling raised by climate change. This includes key debates on a variety of policy related matters, such as carbon pricing or the discounting of the welfare of future generations. In a second step, important normative questions are taken up to address new challenges in welfare assessments of policy making in times of climate change. For instance, we discuss avenues to move beyond GDP in welfare assessments to account for matters of climate justice and the welfare of non-human animals. The course combines a theoretical part where cutting-edge research in the above areas is introduced with a practical part where students work on their own research in one of the areas they select.

column1: 'The strongest feature of the course is the combination of Economics, Law, and Politics comprehensively altogether. Students who aspire to specialize in Political Economy, International Trade and Public Policy, or simply wish to broaden their knowledge about the EU should definitely do this Minor’

‘I would recommend this course to anyone who wishes to learn more about the history, workings and mechanisms of the EU. Moreover, the course is structured, the essay allows one to choose a subject and dig deeper into it and the trip to Brussels has been the highlight of the course!’
Pauline van der Vaeren – Rotterdam School of Management

The effects of European Integration can be felt everywhere. At the supermarket you can buy food from other EU countries and the Bologna process led to a harmonization of academic degrees, making it easier for students to study at different universities in the EU. The Erasmus programme allows many students to go abroad and explore both cultural and educational differences. Furthermore, recent events such as Brexit and COVID-19 pandemic have highlighted the political relevance of European Integration.

This course examines practical and theoretical issues concerning European Integration and touches upon economic and legal implications of the European Union: What is the political background of European Integration? How does it affect us in daily life? Is it possible to preserve a country’s specificities, like culture or social security, while at the same time benefitting from more economic exchange?

column2: • Different lecturers giving insights in their specific field of expertise
• A possible trip to Brussels to visit the EU institutions and meet EU decision makers

• Summarise the foundations and basic principles of the European legal system by using legal terminology;
• Critically assess a European policy area from a legal and economic perspective involving the insights of economic theories and legal rules in their argument.

column1: <body>In this project-course, students will work together with Codarts students to achieve a ‘hit’ song. This does not only involve taking part in/witnessing the creation process of the music itself, but especially the related social and industry practices. This means that students will set a goal for their project (e.g. mainstream or underground scene) and work on getting the song ‘out there’ through the right channels. These projects are presented in a final symposium at the end of the minor. Throughout the course, students are guided by professional songwriters and other music industry professionals such as A&R managers and music publishers. As such, they get a very close look into the real-life production and distribution process of (potential) hit songs.</body>

column1: This course presents a concise overview of financial markets. This includes coverage of a wide array of financial assets, the risks associated with their use, various trading mechanisms employed by exchanges and different forms of organization that govern the interaction among market participants. This will provide students with a solid foundation for understanding the continually evolving financial system, its institutions, its markets, and its products.

We start with an overview of the financial system and talk about the functions of financial markets and institutions. We describe the financial institutions industry and pay special attention to the mutual fund industry. We cover the basic features of (1) the money markets (2) the bond market (3) the stock market (4) the mortgage markets (5) the foreign exchange market and (6) cryptocurrencies. We touch upon valuation of different financial assets, risk assessment, behavior of the financial asset users and implications of the financial market on the economy as a whole.

• Apply theories to explain and predict changes in valuation of various financial products.

column1: <body>This course teaches students how they can use their academic skills and historical knowledge to engage with wider publics. Historians have specific skills which enables them to contribute to public debates or which are useful in professional contexts. The course prepares students for the challenges they will encounter when working as historians in various professional environments, including the museum sector, journalism and radio/television.</body>

column1: <body>The course 'The Public Role of Historians' has the following main objectives. Firstly, students are able to communicate scientific historical knowledge to a broad public. They are able to do so in a number of specific settings, including the museum sector, journalism and radio/television. Secondly, students are able to evaluate different forms of public history. Thirdly, students are able to critically reflect on tensions between professional standards and requirements for public engagement. Fourthly, students are able to carry out a survey study to understand how wider publics engage with history.</body>

column1: The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, then students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
-  discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  critical discussion of the research proposals
-  discussion of and information on possible research methods
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June 2018
The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4.
Theme: The US in a Changing World Order

The rise of the United States as a global power has been one of the defining features of the twentieth century. Throughout the decades, the US has molded the international system in the attempt to create one in its own likeness. This seminar will help the students to reckon with the complex history of US’s positioning in the contemporary world and its varied entanglements in world affairs.

Chronologically, the seminar will mostly focus on the twentieth century. Thematically, it will delve deeper into the various political, cultural, social, and economic dynamics that have shaped both the American foreign policy making process and its outcomes. The seminar will therefore touch on such crucial themes as exceptionalism, empire, Wilsonianism, multilateral diplomacy, world order, hegemony, resistance, and predominance of power. Eventually, the seminar will also sketch out the most important challenges that the US – due its crystallized global leadership – faces in our current days.

By adopting a historical perspective, thus by letting students explore the linchpins of the historiographical debate on US foreign policy and by simultaneously inviting them to critically engage with relevant primary sources, the seminar will provide a broad overview of the US role in the world during the twentieth century (and beyond), and it will stress the transnational nature of the American nation and the structural interdependence it contributed to establishing on a global scale.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114397,2023,The Rule of Law in the Global Legal Context,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. I Kampourakis', 'dr. M Stambulski', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Should businesses be responsible for human rights protection? Does the European Union need to protect judicial independence in Member States? Is the rule of law a concern of states or also of international or even non-governmental organizations? This course discusses such questions against the background of three developments that challenge the functioning of today’s rule of law institutions.

First: the plurality of legal norms in the national, European and inter- and transnational legal context. This multilevel or multidimensional legal order leads to increased complexity, complicated hierarchies, and maybe – depending on the point of view – diminished efficacy when it comes to securing constraints on powerful institutions. Second: the increase in numbers of non-legal actors who are involved in producing official law, but also ‘soft law’ or ‘informal norms’. We may think of NGO’s with ideological interests, lobbyists and large companies with economic interests, and local groups and clans in developing countries. Even if they lack democratic legitimacy, their involvement in the rule making process may be indispensable. Third: the rise of populist democracy and the way the idea of ‘the people’ is contrasted with rule of law institutions. All three of these developments, the transnational increase of legal norms, the variety of actors, and the rise of populism, call into question what the rule of law means today and how it may continue to function.

In this course we will analyse and critically reflect on these developments with the help of theoretical concepts and insights from legal scholarship, legal and political theory, and socio-legal studies. We will illustrate concepts and developments with several cases and social problems debated in today’s legal world.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The overall aim of this course is to give students a contextual understanding of the core legal idea of the rule of law by discussing it against a theoretical and socio-legal background. More particularly, the course aims are that students are able to:

column2: • Distinguish formal, substantive and procedural concepts of the rule of law, and their theoretical, political and empirical implications
• Analyse and relate theoretical and empirical problems of the rule of law in a situation of multilevel legal orders and global legal pluralism
• Analyse and debate how fulfilment of the ideals of the rule of law is challenged by fundamental value differences and private power holders
• Explain problems of monitoring and effectiveness of rule of law and human rights, and how these are affected by the transnational legal context
• Apply the acquired knowledge and insights creatively to contemporary legal and social problems.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116682,2023,The Science of Organizational Change and the Art of Changing Organizations,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. BAS Koene', 'dr. R Kanitz']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Navigating organizational change is very important for managers coping with growing organizations, dynamic markets, shifting societal values, evolving technologies, or global crises. As you assume greater responsibilities in your future career, you must engage with and drive necessary change in your organizations. Therefore, this course addresses the process of organizational development and change, with a particular focus on the role of professional facilitators of these processes. The course is taught as an elective in the MSc HRM but is equally relevant for students from other programs that want to learn more about leading and managing change. While the field of organization development and change has a long history, the past 20 years have shown important advances in how we understand and how we deal with change. This course provides an up-to-date consideration of key insights in the field that are relevant for all who professionally engage with change in roles such as consulting, line management, project management, team leadership, or HR. As elective, the course provides participants an opportunity to explore the issues around people, organization and change and connect them to their own field of study. Overall, the course aims to provide students with essential concepts and knowledge on managing change (the ‘science’) as well as equip students with valuable insights into the creative practice of diagnosing, planning, and executing change (the ’art’).
This course requires active Class preparation and participation for all sessions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Be able to demonstrate how knowledge about organizational diagnosis and organizing, leading and managing change is helpful to understand, analyze and deal with change issues in organizations
• Understand and explain core theories and concepts relevant to navigating organizational change
• Apply concepts related to diagnosing, consulting, intervening, and assessing during organizational change
• Reflect on and improve own teamwork ability
• Adopt a complexity-embracing mindset to navigate change and gain further insights into own attitudes, strengths and weaknesses in dealing with change issues
• Adopt a complexity-embracing mindset to navigate change and gain further insights into own attitudes, strengths and weaknesses in dealing with change issues
• Be able to position and evaluate the role of HR / people management in the change process

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110685,2023,The Social Bases of Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. W de Koster'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This first course in the Politics & Society specialisation familiarises students with the sociological study of politics, focusing on social patterns in public attitudes and political behaviour. How can we understand social differences in support for various value orientations, ideologies, and political parties? And how can we explain social inequalities in political trust and political involvement, both in the formal political domain and in non-institutional politics? There has been a marked decline in Western societies from the 1960s onwards in encompassing political ideologies and the political salience of classic group identities such as classes and religions – a process often referred to as individualisation. This does, however, not imply that value conflicts, voting behaviour, and participation in social movements are no longer socially shaped. On the contrary: old social fault lines have given way to new ones. Systematically combining theories from both sociology and political science with findings from empirical research, this course addresses the contemporary political relevance of these social cleavages. What are their present-day implications? Which groups currently clash over which issues, why is this the case, and how is this related to support for political parties? How can we interpret social differences in anti-immigrant sentiments, political trust, voter turnout, and political protest? And how are these political attitudes and behaviours influenced by online and offline social networks?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Discuss the political salience of old and new social divisions and cleavages;
• Formulate and explain social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours;
• Analyse social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours and apply these to contemporary social phenomena;
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112067,2023,The Strength of the Wolf is the Pack: Ecosystem Thinking in Venturing Settings,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['A Kantilal Tater, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Ecosystem thinking is quickly gaining prevalence in entrepreneurial practice and scholarship. One example of the increasing attention that the ecosystem has been receiving, is the fact that the term was used 160 times in the prospectus of the largest IPO to date. Similarly, a scan of the descriptions of top strategy studies shows that the use of the word had increased 7x over a period of five years. Moreover, practitioners and scholars alike have found ecosystem thinking to have real-world value and important implications for organizational outcomes. However, as with many relatively new concepts, what ecosystems are and how they can be ideally orchestrated has remained somewhat hard to grasp and, are often misunderstood. In this course, we will examine why and how students could apply ecosystem thinking, providing them with a relevant edge in their prospective careers (whether managerial, entrepreneurial, or academic). The course is designed to provide students a well-rounded /immersive learning experience. To facilitate this, the deep dive into academic developments on ecosystems is complemented by the opportunity to listen to and interact with a wide range of guest speakers. The guest lectures are provided by professionals that are leaders in their field and have real life experience with ecosystem thinking. These engagements will enable students to understand how ecosystem thinking is applied and utilised beyond the realm of academia.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Effectively employ ecosystem thinking in their (future) career (whether managerial, entrepreneurial, or academic)
• Understand why ecosystem thinking is relevant, valuable, and necessary
• Understand how the success of a value proposition depends on (inter-) dependencies
• Have a holistic (rather than singular) understanding of what ecosystems are, are not and can be
• Be able to distinguish between different types of ecosystems and understand how and why these differ
• Be able to convey the “why” of ecosystem thinking to others
• Be able to convey the “how” of ecosystem thinking to others
• Understand several “real life” ecosystems (for instance through the multiple guest speakers)
• Have an overview and understanding of the latest academic developments on ecosystems and ecosystem thinking

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115839,2023,Theatre of the Human,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. GH van Oenen'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

We ask how the sciences of man and of the social perceive what is human and how it is situated in the world. Man and world are not universal, static givens but particular, dynamics products of a multitude of forces and institutions that we usually classify as e.g. economic, social, political, cultural, psychological, historical, architectural, ecological. These perspectives are each tied up with (modern) sciences that propose and legitimate conceptions of both the human and the world. Philosophical anthropology both competes with these perspectives, and aims to bring them together, in a continuing attempt to understand how the human relates to the world and how this is expressed in human self-understanding.

In this course, we will investigate this relation as a ‘theatre of the human’: the human is something performed, performing, and performative, acting within, and out of, the conditions and affordances of the world as he (mis)understands, appropriates, incorporates, and abnegates them. The sciences of man and of the social, to be sure, do not just study, describe, and explain this theatre; they are performative as well, in their representation of the theatrical structure and their rendering of the human and the world. The sciences, in other words, are themselves part of the theatre of the human.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - grasping, and be able to productively work with, differences and similarities in the understanding of the human in philosophy, and in the social and cultural sciences
- understanding the theatrical dimension of the human
- ability to apply basic concepts of philosophical humanities to societal issues</body>
