https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115388,2023,Theoretical Foundations of Entrepreneurship and Strategy (ABRI),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This specialization seminar provides students with a solid understanding of the main theories in the fields of strategy and entrepreneurship, as well as insights into the latest developments in these growing research fields. Entrepreneurship research seeks to understand the actions and processes that lead to the creation and transformation of firms and markets, whereas strategy research focuses on how firms develop market strategies, resources and capabilities that enable them to outperform others. The seminar will, first, offer in-depth discussions of the dominant schools of thought in strategy and entrepreneurship (“the classics”), and second, engage students in detailed explorations of several emergent streams of research (“hot topics”).
The schools of thought in strategy that will be discussed include:

column2: • Industrial organization views of strategy (including the work of Porter and cooperative game theory)
• Resource-based views of strategy (including knowledge-based and (dynamic) capabilities views)

column1: The schools of thought in entrepreneurship that will be discussed include:

column2: • Economic theories of entrepreneurship (including work on opportunity recognition and the role of risk and uncertainty)
• Psychological theories of entrepreneurship (including work on cognition and emotions)
• Sociological theories of entrepreneurship (including work on social movements and network perspectives)

column1: The current research streams that will be discussed include:

column2: • Scale-ups and models of entrepreneurial firm growth

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115389,2023,Theoretical Perspectives on Digital Innovation  (ABRI),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructor: Prof. dr. ir. H. Berends (VU), Prof. Dr. M.H. Huysman (VU)

The course focuses on classics and contemporary theories and empirical studies addressing various aspects of the role of technological innovations in organizations, and in particular related to digital technologies. Thorough understanding of theories explaining how technological innovations come about and how technologies influences innovative ways of working and organizing is needed to avoid the use of limited deterministic perspectives of technological developments within organizations and society at large. Characteristic of the course is its focus on practice- and process research approaches, while technology is addressed from a socio-technical perspective. The emphasis is on digital technologies, including digital innovations in sectors such as healthcare, high-tech industry, and creative industry.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114220,2023,Theoretische criminologie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['BJ van Delft, MSc', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'SD Kruit, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Theoretische criminologie beoogt inzicht te bieden in 1) de wetenschapstheoretische uitgangspunten van de criminologie, 2) de verschillende verklaringen van criminaliteit en van sociale reacties, en 3) de mogelijkheden om verschillende theorieën toe te passen op drie probleemgebieden (geweld, fraude & drugs) en te integreren. Door zowel recente als vroegere inzichten aan bod te laten komen wordt een beeld gegeven van de ontwikkeling van de criminologie als wetenschap, en hoe deze door maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen wordt beïnvloed.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• verschillen en overeenkomsten aangeven tussen de verschillende theoretische stromingen in termen van onderzoeksvragen, verklaringen, assumpties en niveaus van verklaring;
• de inhoud van de belangrijkste criminologische verklaringen kennen en toepassen op concrete (kennis)problemen en delicten;
• op basis van informatie over onderzoeksbevindingen conclusies trekken over de empirische houdbaarheid van theorieën;
• aangeven op welke manier maatschappelijke condities het bijeenbrengen en toepassen van wetenschappelijke kennis over criminaliteit en crimineel gedrag kunnen beïnvloeden.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114618,2023,Theories of the Avant-Gardes,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TJ Hoebink'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Avant-garde is the French military term for “front-guard” and is generally used to describe the most adventurous manifestations of modern art. Art that forges ahead, that is innovative, breaks down barriers and challenges the status quo; but at the same time, art that is difficult, sometimes incomprehensible and elitist. Through a combination of the humanities and sociological  perspectives, we will trace the roots of the Western avant-garde, examine the challenges that avant- garde artists faced (and still face today) and discuss whether avant-garde art is still possible in contemporary modernity and if so, in what kind of manifestations. As this course is a seminar, students are responsible for much of the course’s discussions. Students will contribute to the course by being responsible for studying the assigned literature and presentation of case studies that serve as exemplars. In this way, the class is research and communication intensive, relying on student interests to direct the exploration of the course's main themes. The course is entirely in English, requires class participation and presentation, individual and group work, and extensive and creative written work.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between changes in the (visual) arts and popular culture, on the one hand, and changes in society, on the other, for approximately the last 200 years. Students will become familiar with some of the most influential theories of the avant-garde, some of the most influential criticisms and critics of avant-garde art, and some of the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art – from Duchamp’s urinal to Barnett Newman’s abstract paintings, and from Manet to David Foster Wallace. Students will be able to think, read, write and talk about avant-garde art in its socio-historical and aesthetical context; research appropriate literature; create self-formulated questions, and to make an avant-garde art work themselves.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110663,2023,Thesis,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. F Grommé', 'dr. JB ten Berge', 'prof.dr. CL ter Hoeven']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Remark: At least one of the three specialisation specific courses must have been completed with a sufficient mark in order to enroll in the master thesis.

In order to graduate in the master Digitalisation in Work and Society at EUR, a student must write a master's thesis and complete it with a pass. The thesis (a scientific report resulting from empirical research) is intended as proof of scientific ability and is the crowning achievement of the scientific education. The course consists of two elements: the research proposal and the final thesis. Students cannot start conducting the actual research, before their research proposal has been officially approved by the first and second reader on Canvas. Both the research proposal and the thesis must be written in accordance with the APA guidelines.

Experience has shown that a good research proposal is a necessary condition to complete a master thesis of sufficient quality in the allocated time. Therefore, students are required to write a research proposal as a first product for their master thesis. The research proposal is a preparation for a number of important elements of their study, and contains an introduction communicating a research question and added value of the study, a summary of relevant literature and a rough, but plausible underpinning of hypotheses, preparation for the research method, an analysis plan, and a time schedule. The proposal should be written according to the APA guidelines. In consultation with the supervising lecturer, a student may start preparations for the research proposal before the actual starting date of the master thesis period, provided he or she meets the entrance requirements.

Students are expected to write a master thesis following the format of a scientific article. The thesis uses scientific knowledge and insights from the relevant disciplines (psychology, public administration and sociology). The thesis makes both a social and scientific contribution. Empirical material must be analyzed in a transparent and traceable manner, and above all, there must be scientific reflection on theory and practice. Furthermore, the master thesis must meet the usual requirements, such as a clear and systematic structure (introduction with problem definition, working method, theoretical framework, empirical analysis, results, conclusion, reflection), a clear and sound research design, rigorous data analyses, correct source indication, etc. (as described in the manual on Canvas). Agreements about the content and the working method, the phases in the project, deadlines and partial products to be delivered are made in advance and recorded in the research proposal.

For their master thesis project, students can choose to work in thematic groups, which will be supervised by a teacher from Psychology, Public Administration or Sociology. Before the start of the course, the teachers involved in the master thesis supervision will indicate their subjects of expertise and interest, and put their thesis topics online from which students can choose. Students are also free to come up with subjects themselves. Students will be assigned to thematic thesis groups in Block 3. Their theses will share a common topic. A thematic group usually consists of 3 to 5 people who meet periodically. Thematic groups discuss the progress they made, whereby students present their work to each other and read and comment on each other's products. The aim is to create learning circles in such a way that students have a place to share experiences and support each other. If students work on their own topic, it may not be possible to assign them to a thematic group.

column1: After completing the thesis, the student can:
1. Formulate a relevant problem statement for a scientific research project
2. Use scientific literature to develop a theoretical framework and soundly underpin research questions and research hypotheses both theoretically and empirically
3. Conduct a methodologically sound scientific study and justify methodological choices
4. Formulate the theoretical contribution of the research project
5. Independently design and conduct a feasible research project, and adapt to changing circumstances and emerging insights
7. Analyze empirical material in a responsible manner, taking into account the research limitations and ethical and privacy implications
8. Formulate scientifically based conclusions in line with the research question
9. Formulate recommendations based on empirical findings and theoretical aspects
10. Independently write a research report according to scientific standards in the form of a scientific article

column1: All students need to do a research internship. The internship consists of an empirical study which you report in the master thesis. Depending on the master specialization you may be able to choose between a research internship of 32 EC (equivalent to approximately 22 weeks full-time) and research internship of 20 EC (equivalent to approximately 14 weeks full-time). If you do a shorter 20 EC research internship you will do a practical internship in addition to the research internship. The specific rules and possibilities depend on the master specialization that you do. Details are provided on the electronic learning environment.

column1: Many students face challenges with planning, setting goals, stress, procrastination, or motivation at some point in their thesis writing. It is no secret that this can get in the way of progress and finishing a thesis in time.
Whether you’re already experiencing these challenges or just getting started and want to get in front of it: thesis coaching is for you.
Under the guidance of a thesis coach, small groups of max. 10 students will come together in bi-weekly sessions to discuss:

column2: • Set goals for the next two weeks

column1: To really set you up for success, the sessions will also cover topics such as productivity, effectiveness, motivation and balancing energy. Insights from these mini workshops will help during your thesis writing and are also valuable in your next job.
The group has a maximum of 10 participants and is your group for the next 4 months. There is an option to be connected to a Thesis Buddy, for additional one on one contact in between the sessions.
Bi-weekly attendance is expected. Though, you are free to leave the group at any time, when the sessions are not working for you or you’ve finished your thesis.
Thesis coaching supports the process of thesis writing, the actual contents of a thesis will not be discussed during these sessions.

column1: In order to complete the Master of Health Care Management, students are required to write a scientific Master thesis on a topic that is related to one of the subjects covered in the HCM Master. Students write their Master thesis under supervision of a member of the HCM staff. Each supervisor has between 4-6 students that conduct research on a specific theme related to the learning goals of the master HCM. Students may enroll in one of the thesis groups before starting their thesis trajectory. During block 4 through 6, group meetings will be organized during which progress as well as bottlenecks in the thesis process will be discussed.

The thesis trajectory is organized in one course: MSc Thesis. The thesis plan and thesis itself have a workload of 5 and 15 ECTS respectively and thus constitute a major part of the curriculum. The written thesis plan is graded by a PASS or NO PASS. A PASS for the thesis plan is required to start writing the thesis. The evaluation of both the thesis and the defense is conducted by the student's reading committee, which includes the supervisor and at least one co-reader. A pass from the supervisor as well as the reading committee is required before the oral defense of the thesis. The written thesis and oral defense of the thesis should be awarded a minimal 5.5 grade.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The master’s thesis is the final part of the master program. During this final phase, students apply their knowledge and skills in the field of pedagogical and educational research. By formulating relevant academic research questions and carrying out a subsequent research, students contribute to the collective knowledge base of professionals and academics in the field of pedagogy and education.

The master thesis is an academic written product, an academic aptitude test in which students reflect their academic level. The master thesis describes empirical research in form of an academic article and contributes to the knowledge of pedagogical or educational science.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: current insights, key theories, empirical findings, and national and international developments, both within the chosen specialization and at the interface of the three specializations (i.e. ortho pedagogy, family pedagogy and educational sciences);

cultural (i.e. ethnic-cultural, ethical and/or legal), economic, social and/or political developments within the chosen specialization, and related issues, problems and findings (including empirical findings);

advanced methods and models used in the process of signaling and identifying complex, multi-problem pedagogical situations and providing appropriate guidance and support, both at the level of the individual and at the level of systems and institutions;

intervention (or treatment) models of complex, multiple pedagogical problems, including their effectiveness and their application in a diverse context (i.e. diversity in ethnic-culture, social-economic status, legislation, language, gender);
advanced designs and methods for social sciences research.
Students are able to:
<li>

column6: assess and translate complex pedagogical problems into interventions, programs and/or policy, and  analyze and evaluate them;

column5: <li>

column6: carry out research within the chosen specialization and at the interface with other related sub disciplines of the pedagogical sciences;

column5: <li>

column6: analyze complex questions, issues and developments in the field of upbringing and education and form a well-reasoned opinion by integrating existing knowledge and their own understanding with the ability to reflect on the limitations of their knowledge and on the influence of their own and other people’s culture-based norms and values;

column5: <li>

column6: carry out their pedagogic and scientific work with an awareness of ethical and culture-related aspects, in respect of clients as well as test subjects, and to oversee the consequences of their own professional actions;

column5: <li>

column6: work in a multidisciplinary group in a pedagogical context, and competently take on either a leading role or a team role;

column5: <li>

column6: communicate complex themes, either orally or in writing, in a clear and comprehensible way, with the ability to differentiate between different target groups (e.g. children, parents, teachers, policymakers, scientists and other professionals) and accounting for diversity;

column5: <li>

column6: keep up with subject-related developments and developments in society in order to contribute to change processes in pedagogic practice and to innovation in the field of pedagogy; independently engage in a further specialist study program and continue working on their professional development.

column1: The final thesis takes the form of an individual research project. The topic can be chosen by the student, but it needs to be related to one or more of the GMD and PA courses in their track. The thesis must cover a governance issue in relation to migration and diversity, making use of the public administration literature to analyse a specific governance approach. For instance, a comparative analysis of how and why different countries or cities promote inter-ethnic contact, or an analysis of the impact of superdiversity on integration policymaking. Note that an internship is not part of our program.

The thesis trajectory consists of two parts: the thesis-proposal and the thesis-research. During this course [thesis-research] the students will execute the data-collection (where relevant) and analysis for the research question they formulated in the previous course and write their thesis in accordance to the academic standards. The process will be supervised in thesis circles where the proceedings are discussed with the supervisor and peers.

Students will be matched with a supervisor, most likely one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of this master program. This is coordinated by the GMD managing coordinator and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>In the process of conducting the research necessary to answer the research questions, and reporting on the study conducted, students learn:

column2: • to independently conduct the empirical analysis on secondary or primary (self-collected) data, using relevant methods and techniques;
• to independently draw and report academically sound conclusion(s) in relation to the research question and public administration and migration-literature;
• to reflect on the conclusion in terms of limitations, theoretical and/or practical implications, and the need for further research;
• to be able to clearly and adequately communicate the main findings of the study to both an expert and a lay audience.
• to clearly structure and fully reference a thesis.

column3: De master GMCS wordt afgerond en bekroond met een masterscriptie. De thesis vormt het bewijs van vakbekwaamheid bij het integreren van kennis, en het toepassen van kennis om de bestuurlijke complexiteit te begrijpen en er over te adviseren. De scriptie dient wetenschappelijk verantwoord te zijn. De student toont aan in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen onderzoeken en daarover helder te rapporteren. Het scriptieonderzoek wordt uitgevoerd bij een stageorganisatie. Tijdens de stage doen de studenten mee met het werk van de stageorganisatie, ontwikkelen zij een professionele werkhouding en voeren ze tegelijkertijd, in opdracht van hun tijdelijke werkgever, een onderzoek uit dat de basis vormt voor hun scriptie (zie ook de studiegidstekst voor het Atelier Professionele Vorming en de studiegidstekst voor de stage).

Het afstudeertraject wordt in seminars ondersteund. Deze seminars zijn opgenomen in het atelierprogramma. De scriptiebegeleiding vindt plaats in scriptiekringen van 3-5 studenten die verwante afstudeerprojecten doen. Elke afstudeerkring wordt begeleid door een docent. In principe moeten de scripties medio juli afgerond zijn om in september af te studeren.</body>

column1: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
• zelfstandig een relevante probleemstelling formuleren voor de stageorganisatie;
• zelfstandig wetenschappelijke literatuur gebruiken om empirisch materiaal op een verantwoorde wijze te analyseren;
• zelfstandig een methodologische verantwoording geven van de keuzes in het onderzoek;
• verschillende empirische bevindingen koppelen aan theoretische concepten;
• zelfstandig (een) conclusie(s) formuleren in aansluiting op de vraagstelling;
• zelfstandig aanbevelingen formuleren op basis van empirische bevindingen en theoretische aspecten;
• een persoonlijke reflectie geven ten aanzien van het eigen onderzoek;
• zelfstandig een onderzoeksrapportage schriftelijk presenteren volgens wetenschappelijke standaarden.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This EUR minor offered by EUC is designed to provide students with information and analytic skills that are necessary to understand the complex issues that challenge our ability to develop sustainable systems now and in the future. This is a timely subject, as we are living in an era of unprecedented human impact on nature and resources, where the technological revolution has brought us to a point where it may seem that our daily lives are not directly connected to natural laws. In this course, students will acquire knowledge to understand, prevent, mitigate and remediate environmental problems, and to create sustainable (and remunerative) solutions aimed at reducing our impact/ecological footprint on Earth. With this new understanding – or eco-literacy – students will be able to think critically and take environmentally sustainable decisions, which may include transforming environmental problems into business solutions. In order to reach these goals, the course is composed of three integrated modules, i.e., Environmental Sciences, the Economics of Sustainability, and Bio-based Economy (as a sustainable solution to merge environmental sustainability and business). These modules have an interactive, active-learning format (problem-based learning) and have a strong ‘hands-on’ approach, with links to real casestudies in Rotterdam and in the Netherlands. The minor is open to 3rd year students with a background in life sciences, economy and/or social sciences. The content is of special relevance to future green business managers, environmental economists, conservation and environmental scientists, social scientists, ecologists, designers, planners and entrepreneurs who will be engaged in the transition from a fossil-based to a bio-based economy.

column1: The deliberate and purposeful use of imagination and creativity is indispensable in analytic philosophy. In this course we introduce, analyze and discuss various examples of such thought experiments, focusing on
Students develop the academic skills to put “thought experimentation” into practice, i.e., to use their own imagination and creativity for scientific and philosophical purposes.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: (1) The student can recognize and define the main notions, distinctions, problems and “isms” from analytic philosophy.
(2) The student can identify and apply the main views, arguments, objections and authors to episodes, cases and excerpts from analytic philosophy.
(3) The student can formulate, situate and justify the student’s own opinions on key issues in analytic philosophy.
(4) The student can develop and defend a view on the roles of imagination in the student’s own discipline.
(5) The student is able to write a Socratic dialogue in which an analysis of a philosophically relevant concept is put to the test by means of a thought experiment.

column1: Being a psychology student at Erasmus University Rotterdam entails so much more than absorbing knowledge and passing exams. Your academic success is not only represented by quantitative results (e.g., the grades you obtain), but is certainly also determined by qualitative indicators, such as the development of your professional identity, self-guidance, critical thinking, communication, and self-reflection skills. These skills are considered the foundations that underlie a psychologist’s professional work.

During this practical you embark at the first track of your path to personal and professional growth, which will continue throughout the Bachelor programme (and in fact during your entire career thereafter). In the Bachelor Psychology you will work on consecutive learning goals of personal and professional skills centered around self-reflection and -evaluation, self-guidance and interpersonal skills. Since students have different profiles and therefore different learning needs in order to thrive and grow, a free choice of activities is included, which allows you to partly tailor the programme to your own needs.

Meetings will take place throughout the academic year (but more frequently in the beginning). At the start we will explore your new environment and role as a psychology student. Other topics that you will subsequently dive into are (in)effective ways of studying, motivation, self-reflection, and providing and receiving feedback. You will keep track of your activities and reflect on your own development in personal and professional skills.

Thrive Track I is part of the learning trajectory Personal and Professional skills, and extends over all three years of the bachelor program. Saskia Hofman is the practical coordinator and contact person for Thrive Track I. Susan van Rijen is lead of the learning trajectory Personal and Professional skills.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>During this practical you will work on the following learning goals:

column2: • Acquiring an understanding of facilities at the Erasmus University Rotterdam and what it means to be a psychology (fellow) student.
• Connect with fellow students and acquire basic skills that are needed to learn and thrive collaboratively in groups (listening, safe and inclusive behavior, socializing, cooperation).
• Acquiring basic self-evaluation skills. More specifically you will be able to identify obstacles or areas of concern in your own (personal or professional) development.

• Acquiring basic self-reflection skills. More specifically you will be able to describe your development in personal and professional skills (experiences and related context, emotions, behavior and thought).

• Developing awareness of the importance of self-guidance and acquiring adequate self-guidance skills (planning of study activities, organizing study behavior, addressing obstacles or areas of concern, looking ahead to future development).
• Acquiring skills in providing and receiving feedback in an adequate and respectful manner.

column1: Tijdreeksanalyse is het vakgebied dat zich bezighoudt met het modelleren van sequentiele waarnemingen van economische variabelen, zoals maandelijkse werkloosheidcijfers.
Een dergelijk model kan worden gebruikt voor het doen van voorspellingen en voor het inschatten van mogelijke gevolgen van beleid.
Centraal staat hierbij de dynamische samenhang tussen economische ontwikkelingen (bijv. trends, seizoeninvloeden, conjunctuurcycli).
De voornaamste onderwerpen die in dit vak aan bod komen zijn:

column2: • De keus van de dynamische structuur van een tijdreeksmodel

column1: Time series analysis concerns modelling sequential observations on economic variables, such as monthly unemployment figures. A suitable time series model can be used for making forecasts and for policy analysis. A key issue in developing a suitable model for time series concerns the dynamic features of economic variables, such as trends, seasonal fluctuations, and business cycles.
The main topics covered in this course are:

This course uses knowledge of FEB22008X Markov Processes and FEB22005X Econometrics 2, and is required for FEB53116 Economic Research, FEB23006 Quantitative Models for Finance and FEB23016 Advanced Econometrics.

column1: Dit vak geeft een inleiding in beschrijvende statistiek, waarschijnlijkheidsrekening en verklarende statistiek. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan toepassingen van de statistiek in de economie. Onderwerpen die aan de orde komen zijn beschrijvend-statistische maatstaven voor één variabele en de grafische voorstellingen ervan, samenhang tussen twee variabelen en lineaire regressie.

Onderwerpen uit de waarschijnlijkheidsrekening zijn kansrekening, de stelling van Bayes, verdelingen van kansvariabelen, waaronder de Poisson verdeling die een belangrijke rol speelt bij de analyse van wachttijdproblemen.

Verder wordt aandacht geschonken aan het schatten van het gemiddelde van een kwantitatieve variabele en aan het toetsen van hypothesen over dit gemiddelde zowel met als zonder een bekende standaarddeviatie. Ook komt een toets op het verschil in proporties aan de orde.
Tijdens de practica krijgen de studenten gelegenheid te werken aan opdrachten die betrekking hebben op de behandelde stof en die representatief zijn voor het examen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Verwerven van basiskennis van statistische methoden en technieken.
• Het ontwikkelen van een kritische beoordeling van het kwantitatieve denken in een zakelijke omgeving en economie.
• Ontwikkellen van een mogelijkheid om elementaire statistische methodologie toe te passen. In het bijzonder, in staat zijn om elementaire hypothesetesten uit te voeren.
• Ontwikkelen van het vermogen om betekenisvol statistische bevindingen te interpreteren in een bedrijfs- en economie setting.

column1: Het vak bestaat uit twee onderdelen: personeelseconomie en publieke economie.

column2: • Het eerste deel van het vak bestudeert prikkels voor en motivatie van werknemers in organisaties. De rol van monetaire en niet-monetaire prikkels in het motiveren, selecteren en aantrekken van werknemers staat centraal. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn: de effecten van prestatiebeloning op de motivatie en selectie van werknemers, optimaal aanname- en doorstroombeleid, onderwijs, werken in teams, promotie-toernooien, pensioenen en andere secundaire arbeidsvoorwaarden.

• Het tweede deel van het vak richt zich op het functioneren van markten in het geval van publieke goederen, externaliteiten, en asymmetrische informatie, en de rol van de overheid in het verminderen van de inefficiëntie die ontstaat wanneer markten niet perfect functioneren. Ook verdelingsvraagstukken komen hierbij aan bod, evenals de beperkingen van overheidsinterventies. Tenslotte wordt de normatieve discussie van overheidsinterventie aangevuld met een positieve analyse van collectieve besluitvorming.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Begrijpen hoe economische theorie gebruikt kan worden met betrekking tot het werven, selecteren en motiveren van werknemers in organisaties.
• Begrijpen hoe economische theorie gebruikt kan worden voor het bestuderen van het functioneren van markten bij markfalen en de gevolgen van overheidsingrijpen voor efficiëntie en verdeling.

• Het toepassen van concepten en technieken die geleerd zijn bij de eerstejaarsvakken Micro-economie en Wiskunde 1 en 2 voor het analyseren van de effecten van voorgestelde reacties op problemen die besluitnemers tegen komen in de collectieve sector in het bijzonder en in organisaties in het algemeen.

column1: <body>In het vak Toga in Theorie en Praktijk staat een aantal thema’s centraal die als zodanig enerzijds voor de rechtspraktijk van groot belang zijn, en die zich anderzijds lenen voor academische bestudering, in het bijzonder vanuit het voor dit vak gekozen perspectief van de interne rechtsvergelijking tussen de drie hoofdgebieden van het Nederlandse recht. In dit vak zal in het bijzonder aandacht worden besteed aan de rol van partijen, bewijs, spoedprocedures, schadevergoeding, handhaving en alternatieven voor de klassieke procedure. In hoeverre onderscheiden de verschillende rechtsgebieden – na bestudering van de verschillende thema’s – zich van elkaar? Wie kan van wie wat leren? Of is het – vanwege de eigenheid van elk rechtsgebied – niet mogelijk om “best practices” uit te wisselen? Op dergelijke vragen zullen we samen met de studenten antwoord geven.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit vak worden de theoretische uitgangspunten van bewijs en waarheidsvinding bezien vanuit de verschillende rechtsgebieden. De student moet de verschillende bewijsstelsels in het bestuurs-, straf- en civiele recht kunnen beschrijven en vergelijken.

column1: Rechters, advocaten en officieren brengen in hun verschillende functies het recht tot leven en geven het zijn maatschappelijke duiding en betekenis. Togadragers bekleden met andere woorden een verantwoordelijke rol in de democratische rechtstaat. Dit vak gaat over de democratische rechtstaat, wat wordt daaronder verstaan en welke regels en kernwaarden staan in deze staatsvorm centraal. Vervolgens gaat dit vak over de (invulling van de) rol door togadragers die in een democratische rechtsstaat functioneren en over de kernwaarden en de beroepsethiek van deze juridische professionals en de organisaties waarbinnen zij hun werk verrichten. Ook wordt in dit vak, mede vanuit rechtsstatelijk perspectief ingegaan op de betekenis voor togadragers en rechtszoekenden van het grondrecht op toegang tot het recht.

column1: In this course we will focus on nonparametric and semiparametric statistical analysis.

We are familiar with methods such as maximum likelihood or linear regression. These are called parametric analysis as the data are assumed to come from a certain distribution (e.g., normal distribution) or have a certain relationship (e.g., linear relationship).
Nonparametric analysis intends to uncover patterns in data without such assumptions. These methods are much more flexible and robust, but also come at a different cost.

Semiparametric analysis intends to reconcile parametric analysis (fast, easy to interpret but restrained by assumptions) and nonparametric analysis (flexible, robust but computationally expensive and not easy to interpret).

We may also talk about bootstrap related methods, which uses randomisation techniques to extract more information about a statistical estimators, thus providing means for estimating biases, standard errors, confidence intervals and conducting hypothesis testing.
The assessment will be based on two programming assignments and a final exam.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand intuition behind nonparametric and semiparametric methods.
• Apply basic nonparametric and semiparametric methods through own programming and advanced methods by existing packages.
• Identify appropriate methods to apply in different data scenarios.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. Dr. E.C. Perotti (UvA), Dr. F. Greimel (UvA) and Dr. S.J. Huber (UvA)

The term “distributional macroeconomics” was introduced by Benjamin Moll as a replacement for “macroeconomics with heterogeneous agents” to promote the view that the macroeconomy is a distribution of state variables (e.g. income and wealth).

This course will explore some implications of income and wealth heterogeneity for macroeconomic dynamics and macroeconomic policy. First, we want to understand how secular trends (falling interest rates and rising debt) are connected to rising inequality. And second, we want to understand how heterogeneity matters for the aggregate response to macroeconomic shocks.

The focus of the course is on topics, rather than computational methods. (These are covered in second year electives.) We will use simplified models to replicate results from papers and compare the results to empirical evidence. For most topics, we will provide ready-to-run code in the form of interactive Pluto.jl notebooks.
1. Introduction to Distributional Macroeconomics (Greimel)
2. Household Balance Sheets and Recessions (Greimel)
3 & 4. Inequality, Interest Rates and Household Debt (Greimel & Perotti)
5. Monetary Policy, Heterogeneity and HANK (Greimel)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr. B.S.Y. Crutzen (EUR), Dr. J. Delfgaauw (EUR), Prof. Dr. A.M. Onderstal (UvA), Prof. Dr. O.H. Swank (EUR)

The course’s aim is for students to become proficient in the process of development and execution of research ideas within the fields of Industrial Organization and Organizational Economics. Both fields are large. Rather than a broad overview, this course will discuss several topics in detail. This discussion will be representative for both the type of research questions that are addressed in these fields as well as for the methods of study (theoretical, empirical, and experimental). In class, the lecturers will discuss some of their own papers together with closely related papers. The emphasis will be on how the lecturers developed the research ideas leading to the papers. This means that the lecturers will focus less on the technical details, and more on the creative process.

To stimulate students to take part in the creative process, a substantial part of each lecture will be devoted to discuss the students’ ideas for future research based on the papers discussed. For each lecture, students have to formulate an idea for a research project. Their ideas are discussed during the lecture. To facilitate the discussion, students have to send in a written version (about half a page) of the idea on the day before the lecture. Each idea will be discussed during the lecture; active participation of the other students is expected here.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students should have an understanding of the topics and methods used in the fields Industrial Organization and Organizational Economics.
Students should be able to formulate relevant research questions in these fields, to operationalize the research question, and to select and use appropriate research methods.
Students should be able to critically assess the quality of research ideas in these fields.
Students should be able to write well-structured research papers that expose their ideas properly.
Students should be able to orally present their research ideas and give adequate response to comments.

column1: This course investigates the role of non-market actors and institutions in generating economic and political outcomes. Topics vary from year to year.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. State of the art in political economy (in 3/4 subfields).
2. Frontier theoretical models and their application to open and topical questions in political economy.
3. Frontier empirical models, their application to open and topical questions in political economy, and their link to the theory.
4. How to critically evaluate working research and research published in top journals.
5. How to develop, refine, discuss ideas that potentially advance frontier in political economy.
Knowledge and understanding: Students are required to carefully read 1-2 papers per week. Papers vary from classical to very recent ones in different strands of the literature.

Application of knowledge and understanding: Students are required to develop a research question each week based on the material being discussed. They must outline the question and the method or methods (model/data/both) they plan to use to answer the question. Students must also write a research paper that is due after the lectures are completed.
Making judgements: Both activities (weekly research idea + paper) require critical assessments of gaps in the literature as well the develop of research ideas that address these gaps.

Communication: Students present their weekly research question to the class. Student must defend their question and modelling choices to classmates and instructors. Students will learn which projects are not worth doing in these presentations.

Learning skills: This class gives students a disciplined framework for understanding and quantifying problems and issues in political economy. This means that they will learn how to apply accepted frameworks and not just how to reproduce them. The idea of this course is to push students towards research, instead of simply further increasing their human capital.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Businesses need to purchase goods and services, and those purchases need to be paid. In an international context, effecting a payment is not always straightforward. Therefore, this course looks at (international) payment mechanisms between the parties, including electronic fund transfers (EFT) and electronic currencies, at payment mechanisms involving third parties, such as bills of exchange, documentary collection, documentary credit, etc.

Also, companies may need financing, and thus banks, to be able to pay their purchases and working costs (like employees, energy contracts, etc.). In this course credit agreements like (subordinated) loans, overdraft facilities, revolving credit, credit lines, project & real estate financing, etc. will be discussed. Furthermore, we explore the rules and (ISDA)contracts on derivatives; swaps and futures.

The idea to obtain funds without collateral for the bank is a elysian thought. Hence, the course analyzes and evaluated security mechanisms such as liens and pledges, mortgages, bank guarantees, standby letters of credit, etc.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, the students will:
-    understand the concepts of money (including virtual currencies) and payment;
-    have a working knowledge of payment services, payment instruments, electronic currencies and electronic funds transfers (EFT), clearing & settlement procedures;
-    be aware of and be able to work with the contractual tools that parties can use to structure and limit monetary and payment risks;
-    understand general principles of anti-moneylaundering (AML & KYC);
-    have an in-depth knowledge of documentary payment mechanisms (CAD, Letters of Credit) and be able to apply that knowledge to solve cases;
-    have a working knowledge of Bank Payment Obligations (BPO);
-    be able to evaluate and work with different commercial credit agreements and facilities, including export credit, factoring and forfaiting;
-    have an in-depth knowledge of security mechanisms (Standby Letters of Credit, (bank) guarantees and performance bonds) and be able to apply that knowledge to solve cases;
-    have a working knowledge of export credit facilities and credit insurance;
-    be aware of and be able to work with the contractual tools that parties can use to protect their position;
-    have an in-depth knowledge of financial markets, financial instruments & derivatives.</body>

column1: As the world becomes more globalized, and societies become more culturally diverse, it is essential for individuals to develop the skills to communicate effectively with others in intercultural environments. As such, Intercultural communication competences are useful for working in modern organizations in all sectors, including business, public administration, creative industries, education, and health.
This teaching module will be delivered by trainers from Risbo. T

The module was developed in by Dr. Joep Hofhuis, at the department of Media and Communication, of the Erasmus School of History, Culture, and Communication (ESHCC), with financial support from the Community for Learning and Innovation (CLI).

column1: <body>This course provides insight into the opportunities, challenges and tensions of coproducing knowledge in the context of complex societal challenges and provides an introduction to different transformative methods used in such co-production processes. Emphasizing an experiential approach, students will experience a number of transformative methods as participants, and they will work directly with societal stakeholders and their respective challenges to design and implement different interventions making use of co-production methods. This highly interactive course strongly relies on active student contribution, as individuals and in group settings and pays ample attention to the tensions and dilemmas arising in such processes including issues of epistemic (in)justice and directionality. Students are expected to actively take part in the classroom and to work productively in groups – they will engage in three types of activities: cognitive activities pertaining to gaining knowledge about and appraising co-production perspectives and methods; practical activities, including designing and implementing a co-production intervention and experiencing transformative methods, and finally reflexive activities regarding the student’s own role with a group and in co-production settings.</body>

column1: <body>After the course, the student is able to:

column2: • appraise the suitability of co-production perspectives and methods to address specific societal challenges
• design co-production interventions addressing specific societal challenges
• reflect on their own and other’s role in co-production settings addressing societal challenges

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

Striving for self-improvement and self-transgression has always been an essential element of the human condition – from the myth of Prometheus, the Renaissance view on man as “the proud shaper of [his] own being” (Pico della Mirandola), to Nietzsche’s vision of the “Übermensch”. Today, important proponents of transhumanism are leading in different fields of the academic discourse, from the researchers of the “Future of Humanity Institute” at Oxford University, to prominent members of the tech elite such as Ray Kurzweil, Google’s director of engineering, or Elon Musk (Tesla, SpaceX). They propagate strong ideals of becoming “super-humans” and claim that the deficient human being ought to be transformed through technological and biomedical optimisation. Many transhumanists emphasize that they develop a new humanist philosophy, rooted in Enlightenment humanism and other historical sources. Most of them consider themselves members of a progressive movement with idealist goals, some have an explicit political agenda. Critiques argue that they foster an inhumane ideology, promoting ideals of the transhuman being as an output oriented, efficiently working high-performer. One could also say that a hetero white patriarchal is their model for human enhancement. However, some transhumanists are open for a “cyberpunk difference model” that is based on the ideal of unfolding human diversity through technology. Though some transhumanists regard human enhancement as a potential solution to the climate crisis another point of critique is directed against their anthropocentrism, promoting an unchallenged, dominating role of the human being as the master of nature.
This course will offer a critical, yet unbiased and philosophically sound discussion of transhumanist views and ideals.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - You will be able to distinguish between different conceptions and ideals of transhuman or superhuman beings, to put these conceptions into a broader historical context of human self-understanding, and to critically discuss different ideals of being human or of transgressing the concept of humanity in view of future prospects and challenges.

- You will be enabled to critically discuss normative and ideological implications of different transhumanist views and ideals and to articulate your own philosophical position with respect to ideals of being (trans-)human.
- You will develop, carry out and assess the results of a collective thought experiment on the creation of superhuman beings – the “Perfect Human Enhancement Laboratory”.

column1: Transmedia Entertainment and Marketing represents a process where different media-platforms are combined to disperse unique content and produce a story (for a media product or consumer brand), allowing for a unified and coordinated entertainment experience, active audience engagement and eventually building a media franchise. What this means is that a story introduced in a film is expanded through television, novels, and comics; its world is explored through game play or experienced as an amusement park attraction and so forth.

Transmedia is also 360 degrees marketing and public relations; allowing companies to produce content on multiple platforms, reach targeted consumers from different angles and most importantly, enabling audiences to actively collaborate, engage and interact with the content itself.

For students who are interested in subjects such as (corporate) communication(s), (communication, business and change) management, business development, marketing, public relations, branding, journalism, storytelling, entrepreneurship and the creative / cultural industries in general, the course presents valuable and indispensable insights in relation to current studies and latter professional activities.

In this course, we will follow the life cycle of two types of content: media texts and consumer brands by examining (marketing) texts and visual content; narrative structures; active audience engagement; integrated business models; franchises, world building as well as branded entertainment strategies.

We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of this quite recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks. In addition, we will look at alternative approaches to using Transmedia strategies for raising awareness about local, national and global causes, influencing citizen action and creating social impact.

·      Examining how transmedia approaches contribute to key entertainment genres such as science fiction, fantasy, comics, television and games.
·       Examine how transmedia approaches lead to innovations in marketing genres such as PR, product placement and branding, advertisement, franchise and business development.

·      Evaluate various marketing and advertising strategies related to media products or consumer brands;
·      Develop and pitch Transmedia strategies around an existing or a new media product or consumer brand;
·       Develop alternative uses of Transmedia strategies for local / national and/or global causes.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Transmedia Entertainment and Marketing represents a process where different media platforms are combined to disperse unique content and produce a story for a media product or consumer brand or global/social issue. What this means is that the story introduced in a film is expanded through television, novels, and comics; its world is explored through game play or experienced as an amusement park attraction and so forth. This facilitates unique entertainment experiences, active audience engagement and civic participation as well as builds successful media franchises.

Transmedia is also 360 degrees public relations: allowing companies to produce content on multiple platforms, reach targeted consumers from all angles and most importantly enabling audiences to actively collaborate, engage and interact with the content itself. Furthermore, transmedia strategies have also been highly successful as an alternative approach for raising awareness about global causes, influencing citizen action and civic participation as well as creating social impact.

In this course, we will follow the life cycle of different types of content: media texts, consumer brands, global/social campaigns etc. by examining commercial (webisodes, comics etc.) and grassroots (fan fiction, fan films etc.) texts; narrative structures; active audience engagement; integrated business models; franchises, world building as well as branded entertainment strategies. We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of the recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks.

We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of the quite recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks. In addition, we will look at alternative approaches to using Transmedia strategies for raising awareness about global causes, influencing citizen action and creating social impact.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: The course consists of tw0 parts. The first part (80%), is based upon a theme-by-theme analysis of carriage contract, where the various unimodal carriage conventions (Hague-Visby Rules, Hamburg Rules, CMR, CMNI, COTIF-CIM, and Montreal), with a focus on non-maritime transportation,  are compared and contrasted to provide a deeper insight in the various subjects at hand. Also included in this first part will be (non-)sustainable aspects of these conventions (such as e.g. compensation in case of waste shipments; 3-6 PCL and inconsistencies with conventions).  The second part (20%) consists of a study of capita selecta of passenger transportation.
The themes discussed during the lectures include:

A general introduction in which an overview is given of the various unimodal conventions which are part of the fragmented law of transport, and in which conceptual distinctions are made between the contracts of carriage, freight forwarding and storage as well as special kinds of contracts of carriage, such as multimodal transport contracts.

column2: • title to sue under contracts of carriage and bills of lading,

column1: <body>In this practical course, students will have an opportunity to learn directly from experienced forensic therapists. Each week, students will be presented with therapy options that received the most empirical support for specific diagnoses covered in the main part of the course. At the end of the practical course, students will be familiar with five different approaches to treatment, and will be equipt to understand the mechanisms behind all of them. column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In an era defined by rapidly evolving digital connectivity, the foundational concept of trust continues to evolve as a linchpin that defines both personal and organizational communication. However, a significant gap remains as most practitioners and researchers tend to idolize and idealize trust, solely focusing on methods to enhance it, while often overlooking its dysfunctions and the potential alternatives available.

The seminar starts with a philosophical, multi-disciplinary conceptualization of trust, looking at its functions and dysfunctions alike. It will include innovative literature about AI and blockchain, as well as fundamental philosophical scriptures, and relevant social and psychological theories. Through these diverse perspectives, students will gain a holistic understanding of trust's intricate dynamics, both in traditional and cutting-edge contexts.

Then, central models that underscore the role of trust in organizational and corporate communication will be reviewed. By exploring case studies, real-world examples, and theoretical frameworks, students will discern the pivotal role trust plays in shaping relationships, reputations, and strategic decisions within various organizational settings.

Finally, adopting a pragmatic-ethical approach, the focus will shift to the exploration of potential substitutes to trust-promoting messages, with a range of compelling alternatives. This exploration encourages students to delve into innovative communication methods that emphasize security, transparency, clarity, and authenticity. Through collaborative exercises and real-world simulations, students will actively engage in testing these alternative approaches.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students have advanced their knowledge, understanding and awareness of:

column2: • The multifaceted nature of trust, including its functions, dysfunctions, and historical evolution in the context of communication.
• The central models and frameworks that identify the role of trust in organizational and corporate communication.
• Ethical dimensions of trust and trust-related communication practices, including the potential for manipulation and deception

column1: Students have developed the skills to:

column2: • Apply critical thinking skills to assess the functions and dysfunctions of trust-based communication.
• Develop effective communication strategies that leverage trust in organizational and corporate settings, using theoretical knowledge and real-world examples.

column1: Assess the ethical implications of trust-alternative communication strategies, fostering responsible and principled communication practices.

column1: Many of the implications of today’s artificial intelligence technologies only become clear once one understands the way they work.  This course will explore the basic workings of popular modern algorithms and show students how they are implemented, their potential, and their shortcomings. The course does not require any prior knowldege on programming, and students are not assessed on their programming skills. Instead, students will apply theoretical knowledge from the core courses in engaging with the technical dimensions of emerging and seemingly disruptive technologies. They will produce a research paper that explores the societal implications of an algorithm of their choice. Sessions are organized in a dynamic and interactive way, where the first part of each session introduces the algorithm, and the second allows students to test and explore it.

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course we provide students with the art historical, theoretical and critical tools to come to terms with the artistic production – the visual arts, especially - of the post-war period. In doing so, students get a better understanding of both the arts and the contemporary. Throughout the course students combine theoretical discussions on the status of art (‘What is Art?’) and the nature of periodisation (‘what is the Contemporary?’) with critical analyses of singular artworks by canonical artists such as Duchamp and Warhol, Nam June Paik and Gerhard Richter, Jeff Koons and Damian Hirst as well as visits to galleries, museums and exhibitions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.

column1: Politics is a defining feature of all human societies, yet it takes different expressions around the world. Because of its multi-facetted nature, politics is notoriously hard to define. How, then, can we analyse politics across different countries? Does it still make sense to talk about politics in terms of left and right? Does it matter whether you live in a kingdom or in a republic? How dangerous are populists, really? Can ordinary citizens really change the way they are governed?

This introductory course in comparative politics explores basic concepts of political science across a range of political systems. It will also familiarise you with comparative methodology: does political power lie with a president, prime minister or parliament, and why/how does that matter?

The core of the course will cover the most common political systems. You will learn how to distinguish between regime types, different electoral systems, and key aspects of political behaviour and culture. Finally, key issues structuring politics across the world will be examined: the role of ideology, populism, the relationship between democracy and authoritarianism.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

column2: • differentiate between a variety of political systems found across the world
• identify political actors and analyse their behaviour
• retrieve and critically analyse sources of political information

column1: <body>This course offers an introduction to real-world sustainability challenges within an urban context. Cities are the hotspots where climate change, biodiversity loss and socio-economic inequalities affect more than half of the world’s population. But cities are also the natural laboratories for solutions and change that give rise to alternative and innovative futures. Students will learn about the basic infrastructures for provision of basic needs such as mobility, energy, housing, and water. Basic knowledge and insight into how these systems work and what societal transitions could imply in these contexts will be provided. Next, these urban challenges will be put in a global perspective, introducing the students to the global Sustainable Development Goals, Multi-layer model, and Doughnut Economy frameworks. Global conventions on climate change are introduced as responses to these global challenges. Students will critically reflect on the role of city-marketing, cherry-picking of so-called best practices as well as the social dynamics that shape the urban form and its future.   </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>At the end of the course, students have a basic understanding of and can describe the main dimensions of urban sustainability challenges. They understand complexity of urban system for sustainability and the role of cities. Students understand and can explain and identify how different types of agency shape urban development and are able to critically reflect upon the fit (or lack thereof) between interventions and actual transition dynamics. After the course,

column3: • the concepts, theories, and frameworks regarding urban sustainable development
• the key aspects and components of the sustainable urban system
• how proposed theory or framework contribute to sustainability by transformative or incremental change in an urban context
• alternative approaches or framework to guide sustainability transitions across societal systems in urban environments
• (un)sustainability, lock-in and path-dependency in urban development
• the transition approaches and the proposed sustainable frameworks that have been applied to urban sustainable development
• the concepts, theory or frameworks regarding (un)sustainability in urban development
• the transition approaches and frameworks that have been applied to urban sustainable development

column1: The course is structured in four weeks, as follows:
Week 1: Cities as Complex Adaptive Systems.
This week discusses the concepts of wicked problems and complex adaptive systems in lectures and workshops.
This week discusses theories which aim to explain urban dynamics in lectures and workshops.
This week discusses urban resilience and introduces the concept of urban governance. It discusses how increased attention to complexity theory has led to urban governance approaches.
This week offers most time for self-study, a mock exam, and a Q&A, followed by an examination.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, participants will be able to understand the basic mechanisms driving urban dynamics, especially why different (parts of) cities evolve in different directions and at different speeds. We do so by looking at cities as Complex Adaptive Systems (CAS), a theoretical perspective which aims to explain why cities evolve as self-organised dynamic networks, constantly adapting to uncertainty and shocks. The complexity sciences offer a conceptual tool to understand urban evolution by knitting (disciplinary) urban theory together.

column1: The module on governance focusses on analytical approaches that can help describe and explain how technological innovations can be selected and develop from the controlled environment of ‘labs’ to (at times) become the mainstream technologies we use every day. The module presents and discusses the variety of factors and actors that can contribute to the development and selection of a technology and that can affect the chances of its widespread adoption. Several case studies will be reviewed to apply these concepts to concrete, real-life examples (See Learning Objective 3).

The module on governance also critically evaluates the concept of ‘smart cities’ and which challenges and opportunities digitalisation can offer for the governance of cities (see Learning Objective 2). Particular attention will be given to the concept of digital infrastructure and to the opportunities and challenges of (big) data usage in urban decision-making in different cities and regions (see Learning Objective 4).

The corresponding focus course carried out in weeks 10 and 11 of the master specialization is called Algorithmic governance. Students in this group will analyse the opportunities and challenges caused by digitalisation, big data, and big data analysis, and examine how digitalisation can impact more traditional forms of governance and how governments, at different administrative levels, may respond to this.

The module on economics will present the main theoretical approaches to analyse the emergence and impacts of digital transformation and innovation at different spatial levels, from neighbourhoods to cities and from cities to countries (see Learning Objective 5).

The module on economics will also introduce and analyse the opportunities and challenges that the current global digitalisation trends create in the domains of industrial production, employment, and sustainability. Likewise, issues linked to economic geography such as knowledge hubs, and agglomeration economics are explored in this part. These opportunities and challenges will be specifically analysed in the context of urban and regional settings (see Learning Objective 6).

The corresponding focus course carried out in weeks 10 and 11 of the master specialization is called Economic development: Students in this group will focus on economic complexity, technological diffusion, entrepreneurship, and delve deeper into the effects of digitalisation in labour markets.

This module introduces students to some of the main methodological skills that are highly sought after in urban professionals with an expertise in digitalisation and technological innovation in and for cities. These methodological skills prepare students to analyse and evaluate the development and impacts of digital technologies and innovation in cities and regions. In understanding the basics of key methodological techniques, students will not only be able to correctly apply them but also to choose the most suitable approach to adopt for carrying out a meaningful analysis according to the specific issue at hand (see Learning Objective 8).

The module includes an introduction to selected quantitative, qualitative, and comparative methods and offers students a good starting point to develop these skills further. In getting acquainted with this selection of methods, students will learn the basics of Stata and R. The master specialization introduces the students to the foundations of the following methodological skills:

column2: Big data analytics and machine learning applications

It is important to note that the master specialization does not have a technical orientation. Students will be introduced to the main theories and techniques that are conventionally used when steering digitalisation processes in cities and will be able to follow exercises on a set of examples of those techniques in the context of governance and economics of digital transformations.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After the course, participants will have gained a solid grounding towards becoming urban managers specialising in the economics and governance of urban digital transformation and innovation in cities and urban regions. The Learning Objectives of the course are the following:

column2: Understand the innovative and disruptive aspects of technologies in societies, economies, and cities (impacts of urban digitalisation)
Critically evaluate ‘smart cities’ and other digital innovations by identifying socio-economic opportunities and challenges in cities and regions (critical evaluation of smart cities and innovation)
Explain the process of socio-technological development, selection, and diffusion through different examples (socio-technological transitions)
Analyse the opportunities and challenges of (big) data usage in urban decision-making in different cities and regions (algorithmic governance)
Analyse the opportunities and challenges presented by the global digitalisation trend in the context of production, employment, and sustainability, faced by different urban and regional settings
Use fundamental economic theory principles to analyse cases of digital transformation and innovation across various scales: from neighbourhoods to cities and from cities to countries
Apply theories and concepts from contemporary literature to practical examples (link between theory and practice)
Apply selected quantitative, qualitative, and comparative methods for analysing and evaluating digital technologies and innovation in cities and regions (methodological skills)

column1: This is a graduate course in Urban Economics. It treats several important topics in modern urban economics. Location and mobility decisions form the central organizing concepts to study cities, commuting, housing markets and real estate, and transport. After building up the urban framework, we examine agglomeration forces, long-run city development, and sustainability and energy efficiency in cities.
The course comes with a hands-on assignment that changes every year. The most recent assignment was studied the impact of city compactness on air pollution.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To apply economic insights to urban, spatial and location choice decisions
• To understand location choices and to explain how cities and regions’ sizes, wages and land price develop as a result.
• To infer the value of amenities and property, based on information from house prices and wages and to comment on policies (transport, housing).
• To explain how cities develop in the long run.
• To apply these insights to a real-life case and write a (concise) report.

column1: The UESC specialization is structured around the insight that true climate neutrality and resilience require systemic, nexus thinking around practices and key natural resources, such as land, water, and atmosphere, representing the “layers” of the climate adaptation and mitigation focus of the UESC specialization.

The program is divided into seven modules starting with an introduction and the problem statement, covering the layers land, water, and atmosphere, and ending with sustainable transitions, synthesis, and advisory assignment. These modules are summarized as follows:

The first module introduces the storyline of the specialization track and outlines principles of some key theoretical frameworks, including layer models and nexus thinking, “Doughnut Economics”, and sustainable transition approaches.

This module presents the environmental, social, and institutional background knowledge related to climate change, which is required to better understand social inequalities, regional risks, and climate extremes.
This module introduces the links between climate and the water cycle and explains the interplay between climate change, sea level, clouds, rainfall, future climate, and extreme events.

During this module details of the principal ways in which land-based drivers can influence the climate are covered. The module relates climate neutrality to land markets and rights, land developments and risks, governance, and policy.

This module illustrates how urban air pollution develops and explains the UHI effect, including human health effects and mitigation efforts. It ends with the relationship between heat problems, air pollution and GHG emissions.

This module will contextualize sustainable transitions and climate neutrality with real-world practical problems, applications, tools, such as energy transition, water resiliency, nNature-Based Solutions and ecosystem services.
During this module, students are challenged with questions about climate justice, governance implications, workshops, and serious games, linking sustainable transitions to thesis proposals.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Reflect on the land/water/atmosphere nexus and its interlinkages with climate resilience and climate neutrality.

• Critically engage with frameworks of sustainable development, such as “Doughnut Economics” (Kate Raworth, 2017) and sustainable transition frameworks, risk frameworks, and their relationship with climate change.
• Critically examine the concepts of climate adaptation and mitigation and their various components and dimensions, in theory and practice.
• Investigate climate mitigation and adaptation tools and solutions to realize climate neutral and resilient cities.
• Explain the mutual relationship between environmental resilience and other forms of resilience (social, economic, and institutional).
• Evaluate the multi-faceted principles of “resilience” and “risk” and the application of these principles to land, water, atmosphere, NBS and to climate resilience in urban areas.
• Design and present an integrated climate adaptation and mitigation strategy for a client organization, based on actual data, circumstances, and needs.
