column1: The course is organized in 2 distinct modules.

Urban governance: starts with an introduction to urban theory and the complexity of the urban context. It then focuses on the changing role of government and other key stakeholders in the governing of and decision making in a city. Students discuss and debate on the relevance of theories of hierarchies, markets and network governance for urban governance.

Public Private Partnerships: introduces the concept of Public Private Partnerships (PPP’s) an instrument for urban governance. The students work on a practical case of business planning for PPPs, and use knowledge and skills gained to make key policy decisions on the appropriateness of PPPs in the urban context.

column2: • Urban Governance – overarching module: this module looks at the increasing complexity of cities. It introduces the difference between government and governance, articulates what urban governance is, and outlines the trends in theory and practice on governance. The participants discuss why urban governance is an essential pillar of sustainable development and review the different theories that underpin urban governance. Discussions revolve around the current academic debate on the utility of hierarchies versus new public management in the face of complex cities demanding decision-making that mirrors that complexity. Participants look at and assess the empirical evidence on these streams of theory and assess the extent to which these approaches have resulted in the outcomes intended. They spend a session analysing a complex decision-making process applying the core concepts of network governance theory (actor, game, network and network management analysis).

• Public Private Partnerships – a mechanism to implement and institutionalize urban planning and policy: Since the 1990’s PPP’s have become an important approach to streamlining cooperation and risk sharing between the public and private sectors and achieving value for money in service provisions. This module introduces participants to different rationale, objectives and forms of PPP’s. Participants discuss and assess under what conditions PPP’s can be successful vehicles for urban development. They apply a framework to analyse the 'marketability' of PPPs; this framework aids governments to make sound policy decisions related to PPPs.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After the module participants should be able to:

column2: • Differentiate the theories that underpin good governance; and understand the relevance of hierarchies, markets and network governance for urban governance.
• Deliberate on the trends in the nature of the urban context and its implications for governance.
• Distinguish the various forms of decentralization as an instrument of urban governance and analyse the impacts of the shift of power to local governments.
• Discuss, distinguish and debate the rationale for and utility of bureaucracies, vs. new public management vs. complex decision making in the complex world of today;
• Discuss the rationale for public private partnerships as a mechanism for good governance and understand the reasons for a shift to public private partnerships in service provision.
• Discuss the theories that underpins PPPs and understand what PPP’s are;
• Discuss and analyse how and under what conditions PPP’s can be used to institutionalize private sector participation in urban development.

column1: <body data-gr-ext-installed="""" data-new-gr-c-s-check-loaded=""14.1068.0"">The course is organized in 4 different components:

column2: • Urban Governance – decision making in situations of complexity: In this component, we look at theories underpinning urban governance and focus on trends to networked forms of governance. Network governance is seen as an alternative to markets and hierarchies, in particular in situations of increasing complexity and uncertainty. Government is no longer the lead actor in development, but one amongst many. This implies a new role for government, a role in steering and managing horizontal relations.

• Urban Policy – policies for urban development: This component introduces the meaning of ‘policy’ and looks at what makes a policy “urban” as opposed to sectoral. We will discuss the impact of changing concepts (for example, integration, decentralization, participation, neo-liberal approaches) on urban policies, as well as what makes a good policy.

• Urban Planning – this component focuses on the different meanings and interpretations of 'urban planning' and the changing role of the urban planner. This is also in the context of increasing complexity. It highlights trends in concepts, in planning approaches and the shift from traditional land use planning towards more strategic forms of planning.

• Local Government Finance – Local government finance is about the revenue and expenditure decisions of local governments. It covers the sources of revenue that are used by local governments such as taxes (e.g., property, income, sales), user fees, and intergovernmental transfers. It also includes ways of financing infrastructure using operating revenues and borrowing as well as charges on developers and public-private partnerships. Furthermore, local government finance also addresses issues around expenditures at the local level and the accountability for expenditure and revenue decisions, including the municipal budgetary process and capital investment planning.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After the module participants should be able to:

column2: • Describe the differences between network governance theory, traditional public administration and new public management, argue the relevance of the network governance approach in complex decision-making processes, analyse a complex decision-making process applying the core concepts of network governance theory (actor, game, network and network management analysis) and recommend how to improve the performance of networks.

• Describe the meaning, dimensions and objectives of urban policy, as well as the importance of the policy process and tools for implementation, deliberate on the definition of and nature of public interest and who determines it and analyse the quality of policy documents using a set of objective criteria.

• Understand what planning is and its relevance for intervening in urban areas, assess different approaches to planning, the values that underpin them and their influence on the planning outcomes and processes, and analyse the role of the planner and other stakeholders in the planning process.

• Discuss the key principles and elements of local government finance; critically reflect upon the theory and practice of the local governments in Infrastructure Asset Management in a given context. Apply economic and financial analysis to investment projects relevant to local governments and incorporate uncertainty and probability in decision analysis and argue, using the principles of economic and financial analysis, how decisions are made in infrastructure investment projects.
• Understand the links and relationships between the different module components and analyse what these linkages mean in practice
• Within a multicultural team, jointly discuss and mutually agree upon decisions

column1: The second half of the 19th century witnessed a period of rapid urbanization in Europe. The life of the city dweller, in particular in Europe, became economically, socially and economically dominant. This course orientates on the major transformations:
- Urbanization, the growth of cities and the shaping of the modern global city
- The port city as specific city (second city, shock city) and its relationship to the global city
- The planned modern city and ideal models on urban planning
- Cities as places of migration and superdiversity
- Urban visual culture, urban icons and the mediatisation of the city
- Urban heritage, public history and the role of the city museum

Rotterdam, originally one of the many typical Dutch commercial medieval cities, showed a spectacular growth in the 19th century. Rotterdam became the working city of the Randstad conurbation and turned into a world port after the Second World War. The modern urban history of Rotterdam – considered to be the most dynamic city of the Dutch metropolis since 1850 – is used as a case study to discuss the impact of 19th and 20th century urban transformations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Cities have played a significant role in the transformation of the world and today a majority of the world population lives in cities. Many scholars relate this urban revolution to a new round of globalisation. However, globalisation is a much longer-term historical process. This course focuses on 19th and 20th century’s urban transformation and gives an introduction on global urban history, using Rotterdam as a case study.</body>

column1: In a world with ample resources, knowledge and skills, inequalities are growing across the globe. This manifests itself in economic inequality, social inequality, gender inequality and housing inequality. Adequate housing is a basic need, a right and not a privilege. It is considered a human right (CESCR, General Comment 4, 1991, Art.11 (1):13/12/91), not a commodity subject to market forces. Housing is more than a roof over one’s head. Access to adequate housing means that individuals and families can secure safe, affordable, and adequate shelter for themselves and future generations. It implies that families have the ability to find and maintain their physical and emotional well-being and an appropriate place to live and meet their social and economic needs, allowing them to become part of a larger community network.

However, access to adequate housing, especially in urban areas, is a perpetual global challenge, with rising housing inequality and vulnerable groups being left worse off. The growing number of displaced, homeless, and expanding informal settlements with limited access to infrastructure and services around the world is evidence of the deepening challenge and systematic failure.

Land inequality grows around the world and stands as a root cause of housing inequality and access to public services and amenities. Unequal access to land is at the root of some of the most pressing societal concerns and injustice. Due to the nature of land, being limited in supply, fixed, and highly in demand and the value is determined by the value society places on its economic and social uses, land for non-profitable uses such as affordable housing is not prioritised but relegated to the side lines. Land can be a major engine of shared prosperity or one of the most pervasive drivers of inequality.” – Guereña and Wegerif (2019). Therefore, addressing land justice as it concerns housing justice and access to urban services is pertinent to achieving society’s shared goals, identified in the New Urban Agenda (NUA) and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

The master specialization will theoretically review and approach housing and land justice and injustice complexities and explore the practical implications, real-life outcomes, and consequences. It will examine (in)justice and (in)equality through socio-political, socio-legal, economic, environmental and governance perspectives regarding enabling land and housing rights and access to land, adequate housing, and basic urban services. The specialization will focus on examining and evaluating land and housing socio-political economy and the complex process of land and housing in relation to equity and social, gender and environmental justice by analysing the complex theoretical debate surrounding these topics and their place in sustainable development and building resilient urban and peri-urban communities and societies. Adequate housing will be operationalized by applying the 5 A’s Principles of Adequate Housing, namely Availability, Accessibility, Affordability, Acceptability and Adaptability while at the same time looking into how these principles interact with the housing supply value chain in which land assembly and acquisition is the first step. </body>

column1: At the end of the module 1, students will be able to: Analyse complex processes of urban housing and land (in)justice and their interrelations with social, environmental, and gender (in)justice.

At the end of the module 2, students should be able to: Critically analyse the interconnectedness of property rights, land markets and land value capture instruments and address the resulting effects on equitable and sustainable development.

At the end of the module 3, students should be able to: Critically reflect on the functionality and applicability of LVC regulatory and spatial instruments aimed at land values increment redistribution for equitable development.

At the end of the module 4, students should be able to critically assess the role of housing in the economy and the environment by assessing the contribution of affordable housing to the economy and urban sustainability objectives.
At the end of the module 5, students should be able to:

column2: • Apply the principles of adequate housing, namely availability, accessibility, affordability, acceptability, and adaptability, to housing policies and approaches.
• Evaluate to what extent current policy approaches to formal and informal housing address the housing challenge in relation to the provision of adequate housing, equity, and socio-spatial justice.

column1: At the end of the module 6, students should be able to: Critically reflect on the complex land and housing nexus as it connects to governance, socio-spatial development, urban sustainability, and justice.
At the end of the workshop, students should be able to:
Propose tailor-made strategies to address sustainability issues and evaluate socio-spatial and environmental justice pertaining to land, housing and urban services.

column1: Urbanization has led to the enormous expansion of cities since the beginning of the 19th century. In 2012, UNICEF predicted that by 2050 more than 70 percent of the world population is likely to live in cities. In this module we will discuss various contemporary issues that characterize urban areas, such as gentrification, stigma, migration, digitalization, crime, deviance, and insecurity. Different research traditions in the field of urban studies will be applied to study these issues, thereby combining insights from disciplines such as criminology, sociology, and social geography. Students are expected to write an academic paper that includes a literature review on one more of these issues and a small empirical study. The goal of the course is to critically assess how various global processes shape the contemporary urban landscape.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Upon completion of the module, you will be able to:

column2: • Apply your up-to-date knowledge from the (urban) sociological scientific literature on cities and urban issues in relation to deviance, insecurity and crime;
• describe characteristics of urbanity and relate them to (street) culture, deviant behaviour and insecurity;
• describe and interpret the influence and impact of global transformation processes on local practices in world cities;
• reflect critically on (policy) reactions to urban developments in areas of employment, housing, leisure and safety, in particular in the light of unintended effects of policy;
• incorporate empirical data in your academic expressions (written and verbally);
• write an academically structured paper as well as translate this academic paper into a blog
• Write an extensive academic book review (IMARC students only)
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In both popular imagination and academic discussions, we are regularly told that the future is urban. Rapid and new forms of urbanization are changing what cities are and what it means to live in city-regions. This course is an invitation to travel to some cities in Latin America, Africa, and Asia with the aim of cultivating a comparative perspective on urbanization processes. Through this intellectual journey, we will absorb the lessons that cities in the non-West impart about categories and methods for understanding urban conditions. Along the way, we will encounter 5 key themes which animate contemporary urban research: Housing; Transport; Climate Change; Urban Health; and City Nights. In wrestling with the major social problems which assail cities and the hopes they offer its inhabitants; we will familiarize ourselves with the vocabulary of critical urban theory.

It is said that a good traveller goes away from familiar places so that they may return with a new pair of eyes with which to view their environs. At particular junctures of this module, we will return to Rotterdam's experiments with city living to contemplate the meanings of urban social justice in   a profoundly unequal world.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After having completed this course, you are able to:

column5: explain the main similarities and differences between sociological, criminological and medical/psychological perspectives on deviance;
distinguish – and give examples of – different types of social norms
explain and apply theories about criminalisation;
explain and apply sociological explanations of deviant behaviour;
explain the complex relationship between social cohesion and deviance with a focus on neighbourhood social cohesion and neighbourhood crime;
explain how and why there is social inequality in punishment;
explain and apply sociological insights about the effects of punishment with a focus on imprisonment;
understand and explain the merits and limitations of the main data sources and research methods in the sociological study of deviance;
conduct a small empirical-theoretical study on a ‘deviance’ topic;
